description:
Tried some yesterday and I have to say the tacos were very good!
I ended up eating 5!! Very yummmmmy!
author: Jessica S.

description: Yummy!  $2 for a large taco - really liked the roasted chicken.  Tasty filling and cheap.  (Better than the pork or the regular chicken)
author: Vivian W.

description:
OK, I tried really hard to rmember the name of this truck cuz I saw them at the SJ Earthquakes game, and they are prob some of the best that I have ever had.

There was a line, and was talking to my bud 'bout getting the Cabeza tacos. 

For those of you who don't know, cabeza is an entire cow head that is cooked/steamed overnight with a variety of spices. All of that tender cheek, and tasty fat/muscle ends up just falling off of the head! It usually is super flavorful.

Now the ambiguity with me lies with what is included in cabeza (depending on you you ask, it's got the eyeballs, tongue, ear, nose, etc - but not sure about the brain).

Now, at Super Taqueria, I have seen "cabeza" advertised as cheek meat, and I believe that this is all it is, since all I taste is that tender meat - no brains, eyeballs, etc. It's got the meaty texture, but nothing squishy.

On the internet, they say that in Mexico, you usually specify the part of the head that you want.  There was also one source that said it also included the brain; none of the other sources specifically said that this was included.

At this truck, they advertise it as "head/cheek". The guy in front of us overheard me, and freaked out! He said that "he ain't never touching that stuff that "includes brains, eyeballs, and stuff..." 

Personally, I wasn't too sure that they usually include brain in cabeza since it's considered a whole other delicacy  altogether, and when my dad was meat-cutting in Watsonville, it was always sold separately. Not 100%, though.

Nonetheless, I ordered a pair (of tacos!). I can't remember the exact price, but they were less than two bucks each.

The result - soft homemade tortillas came with really good helpings of really aromatic and smooth cabeza topped with marinated carrots and grilled jalapenos. Everyhing was soooooo good, and the meat juice/sauce/broth was just ridicuously dripping out of them! 

OK, that age-old question that I posed up above...did I think that the cabeza came with brains and eyeballs this time 'round? 

My answer is that it definitely more than just the cheek meat...there was something different about the flavor (in a good way) that tasted like there was perhaps the collagen or tendon in it as well. Brains? maybe a little, but one can never be too certain. 

Let's put it this way - it was a tad little bit more squishy than I've had at other places.

I'd surely order them again from this truck if I had the chance!
author: Jimmy L.

description:
The worst case of food poisoning ever!!!!!!

On Wed Sept 19th I hadn't eaten anything all day and thought I would try out El Tonayense and ordered a pollo asado (chicken) burrito.  
While eating the spicy burrito I could tell I was going to get heart burn later.  Little did I know I would be up at 1:00am throwing up for hours well into the next day. This has cost me two days of work and now Sat Sep 22nd I still can't eat without feeling nauseas. 

I usually don't write reviews about food complaints but after reading other reviews I see that this is not the first case of food poisioning for this truck, nor the first with food quality and safety issues.  

Note: This truck also has multiple Yelp postings with other food safety and health related complaints.

They should probably be inspected for health issues.
author: Joan F.

description:
My husband LOVES the El Tonayense taco truck in SF (the one by Best Buy), so it would only make sense that he would want his beloved tacos as part of our wedding. 

We hired one of the El Tonayense Taco Trucks for my wedding reception, to provide the midnight snack for my guests. Overall, I was pretty happy with the service. Guests were happy with their tacos & Jarritos soda, and the portions were just right as a 'little treat' to our guests after a night of drinking and dancing. 
 
Pricing is VERY fair considering that they had to come outside of San Francisco on a Saturday night, during prime food-truck hours! Vinicio (gentleman working with me on scheduling and pricing at their home base) was very responsive with my initial inquiry and super helpful when helping me decide what to serve our guests.
author: Melanie C.

description: It was a pleasure working with El Tonayense Taco Truck. We hired them for our wedding and the guests loved it. They came on time and did their thing...and then they gave us all the leftover food because we did not spend our limit! More tacos all around!
author: Schelly Y.

description:
If you're a fan of tacos...

If you don't mind eating standing up...

If you can take a cab to the Best Buy...

THEN DO IT.

This taco truck served what are inarguably the best tacos I've ever eaten...in my LIFE. I know, I know. It seems like another tired Yelper making some hyperbolic review for the sake of sounding kitschy. Not this guy, not this time. 

Get a variety of tacos done super style for some sour cream, cheese, and guac. You can get any taco for $2 + .50 for super style. Prices include tax. I highly recommend the carne asada and carnitas tacos bout of this world.
author: Jake K.

description:
Two stars instead of one because it was better than taco bell.

My burrito was made very sloppily and it didn't have enough meat in it to even notice it was a meat burrito!

The flavor in whatever sauce they used was NOT authentic mexican at all, and although we asked for spicy salsa, it tasted lighter than mild!   

On top of all of this, the guy working at this place was giving off bad vibes.
author: Stephie M.

description:
My "taco/burrito" spot when I head home after a morning jog....and to do some side-shopping at Best Buy :)

I'll say this taco truck is one of the few places where the taco, burrito, quesadilla, etc. is NOT oily. I usually stick to Carne Asada or Al Pastor, but so far, every type of meat I've chosen has been marinated well and taste awesome. You know how when you are towards the end of your burrito, that whole section is usually pretty saucy and wet due to 'gravity'? Well, the way they made the burrito here...it doesn't get soggy all the way to the last bite.

Got to mention the service as well. It is top-notch and the dudes in the truck are nice and aware of who ordered what (I'm especially grateful when there's a long 'waiting' line and some customers order the same type of burrito, so you can imagine some 'hey, i ordered that burrito so I'm going to take it even though I just ordered 2 mins ago' syndrome). That's right muchacha....I have my eye on you next time I'm there....you line cutter...and you...'but I ordered that burrito too!' Grrrrrr
author: Dave L.

description: I just polished off the tastiest torta and taco and felt moved enough to write a review. So so good!!! My al pastor taco was perfectly seasoned without being greasy (usually the norm for al pastor tacos). The pollo torta was equally as tasty. Once again my hands were not dripping in grease and the flavors were spot on.  The end of the bread was a bit tough, but other than that just delic! Prices were also completely reasonable. You'll be eating in a Best Buy parking lot, but rest assured I will certainly be back for more from this taco truck..
author: Ritu K.

description:
tacos and mexican coke!

Happy Hour Part 3 - the end

This truck used to come on tuesdays at my workplace. Tasty, greasy, and filling. This was Taco Tuesday done right. Finally it was back, and for happy hour. I was close to full after some yakis and belgian waffles, but I couldn't resist finishing off with some tacos.

I decided to continue my adventurous streak (http://www.yelp.com/biz/bun-bo-hue-an-nam-san-jose#hrid:mTR_cmS5hlWDy1WodIQuzA) and ordered a cabeza taco and a lengua taco.

:: Food ::

Cabeza taco (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/uGM7PAmP2utWXjYcZkVpQQ?select=_tn2zRGGu5KQ_zHyuhM9jw) is made with beef head meat and cheek. It was dry and had a smokey flavor to it

Lengua (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/uGM7PAmP2utWXjYcZkVpQQ?select=ILBu52D4O8ALLXJlrWyjQw) taco is made with beef tongue chopped up. My boss had quite the reaction when I told him (vegetarian) what I was eating. It was chewy but very flavorful.

The tacos came on a double layer of corn tortillas which weren't dry at all. But for me, a single layer would have sufficed (I pulled off the other layer).

:: Service ::

They screwed up my order and dumped onions on it. But they replaced it quick enough with another order. Thanks guys.

Good tacos.
author: Christina C.

description: My favorite burrito in San Francisco. Definitely recommend the carnitas super burrito. Just $7!
author: Mariusz L.

description:
I've been hearing a lot how good the El Tonayense Trucks are, so when i walked out of my building to get dinner, I was super stoked to see the Truck parked across the street.  Ditched my Whole Foods plans and illegally ran accross a busy 4th street.  

Turns out the truck was doing a catering gig, but they were cool with serving me.  We all know how good these trucks could be nowadays, and to see what thats actually serving real tacos...well they expectations were high.  

As much as I wanted it to be great, the carne asada burrito was okay, and the same goes for the Al Pastor tacos.  The flavor was good, but they were lacking the fullness of some of the stuff you can get at a taqueria or other trucks (forgot the name, but the one that was in front of the incase party was sooo good).  

Anyways, it was a good solid burrito, but I've had better.   I mean if Indian, Chinese, Filipino, Korean, Southern Comfort Food, and French Cuisines can be made to 5 star quality, you would think the the "Taco" truck should have it mastered.  Maybe I got to go to one of their regular spots rather than one hired for catering.  I just expected more from a "TACO" truck.
author: Veasna H.

description:
For years I have been coming to both trucks, urging friends to try their amazing tacos, LONG before the food-truck culture caught on here in SF, LONG before their NYT Food Review a number of years ago (8? 10?) took them out of secret-awesome-food into the open.

Recently, there seems to be new people running the show. They confuse mild with picante (happened three or four times at the Best Buy location) and .... the new people at the Best Buy location don't love this business anymore.  The lady there gets super confused and....yep, the customer is not right. Today: after taking an order for four tacos to go, and giving change from a $20 that matches the order, the lady in the truck INSISTED that my friend had neither ordered or paid for four tacos and gave him such a bad time (did she really think this incident wouldn't end up on Yelp? really?) that he finally showed her his change and she STILL insisted she didn't take his money.  

really?   Please bring back the old people. Did they sell it?

No more Tonayense.  :(
author: S T.

description:
My absolute favorite taco truck in the whole wide world! They were there when I was once a poor intern working at 19th and alabama. I would walk about 4-5 blocks just to get cheap $1.50, easy and filling tacos for lunch. 

Oh how I miss El Tonayense! I shall come and pay homage one of these days.
author: J M.

description:
Came here after a solid hike at a friend's recommendation..we love our taco trucks in LA but this is pretty damn good! 

3 carne asada tacos. 30 seconds later. another 3 carne asada tacos please. 
That is how good they are! 6 tacos in a matter of 2 minutes. Its obscene but that;s how tasty they are. 

And then I had to run around the block to burn it off...
author: Mich Q.

description:
A Michelin rated taco truck? Is there such a thing? Yep! El Tonayense! 

Passed up this truck every time we went to Best Buys but it was a sunny taco sunday and we decided to try this place after doing a quick return at Best Buys. 

Cash only, tacos are $1.75 each. We got the asada, carnitas, and pastor tacos. Definite YES for the pastor and carnitas. Asada was only o.k. The truck also serves agua fresca and we got a yummy horchata to wash down our food. A perfect way to practice my Spanish too!
author: Betty C.

description:
I ate tacos from this truck during the gdgt Live event 2010.  They were free for the first 500 people, or so.  Their truck is so colorful!

The taco I had was pretty good, it's hard to judge an entire truck based on one taco, though.  The carne asada was pretty flavorful, had plenty of spice (I like), and was huge!
author: Wally W.

description:
Got the beef, tongue and neck taco.  Beef was dry.  For a taco truck, its decent.  $1.75 for 1 taco, cant really complain.. but then again, i had to eat 3 tacos to get full, whereas i can get 1 taco from elsewhere for $3-4 and be happy.  

Overall, its A-OK
author: Anna W.

description:
El Tonayense is a truck I have followed for years and have said over and over hands down the BEST taco food truck in the SF Mission district.  They park at 22nd and Harrison and usually there is a long line.  I always ask for beans and I love the carrots and peppers!  Their meat never has fat on it and is tasty but not greasy or salty.  

When I saw that they were sponsoring the SF NACE March meeting at the SF Winery on Treasure Island,, I was ecstatic.  Always a great experience, and they cater too!  Check 'em out.  Tell them Babaloo sent you!
author: Bahvee V.

description: Awesome awesome cheap tacos. Al Pastor are the go to's and are still not beat by fancy pants restaurants.
author: Jim O.

description:
I got a super quesadilla with chicken for lunch last thursday and ended up with the worst food poisoning all thursday night, friday and saturday morning.  i have never felt sicker in my life!

On top of that, I don't even think the quesadilla tasted that good. It was too greasy, which made the tortilla soggy and soaked by the time I sat dow to eat it.  The chicken was mushy and the avocado tasted old. Never going back!
author: Melissa O.

description: This place rocked my sox off.  Just happened to be walking by and wanted to try a food truck while I was in San Fran.  This truck didn't let down.  I ordered the steak burrito and while waiting they gave me a complimentary taco that was fresh and spicy on a corn tortilla.  The burrito was a great choice because they use a tasty rice and bean to compliment the steak.  A nice green sauce to go along with a few crunchy onions makes e burrito.  Walked by the area again the next day hoping but they were gone.  Good show Tonayense!
author: Jared M.

description:
I am not a complainer by any means and this is my first post on Yelp to prove it.  That's how important I feel this info is to your wallet, pallet, and health.  

We have lost a great food tradition in SF and I feel very sick right now only after a few bites from this disgusting garbage of a burrito which has left a thick, filthy, layer of old meat grease coating the inside of my mouth which is making me even sicker as I type.  Do you want that?  I didn't think so.  Do not eat here.  I repeat DO NOT EAT HERE!!! I hope some of the other trucks still abide by the old recipe but this truck no longer does.  Instead they serve an inedible, cheaply made, impostor version of the real ET.  So sad.

I have lived about a half mile from the ET truck in frnt of Best Buy for the last ten years and have gone here religiously throughout that time but my last visit was in October 2013, so a few months had gone by and I was missing the incredible flavors that ET used to offer.  The burritos were something of an anomaly in every way.  

- First of all they were extremely affordable and for those of you who have lived in SF over the last 15 years, you've watched the gentrification SF quickly hike up prices even on the cheapest of foods i.e. burritos, so this place was 6 bucks for a burrito, now it's 7 and not worth it at all.

- Most notable was their signature light green colored, cilantro rice. This no longer exists.  This is such a shame, I am really at a loss for words.  It made their food stand out and stand alone pretty much.  It was novel.  It was amazing and food doesn't typically excite me.  It was certainly exciting. Now it is run of the mill spanish rice but greasy and cheap.

- The beans and the meat, if you went that way, were freshly made, not greasy, and hot.  The beans and meat today were cold.  The meat was old and lets just assume the beans were too because why would you have fresh beans and old shitty meat?  The meat was greasier than the worst taqueria one could possibly imagine.  I want to die right now from how greasy my tongue still feels a good half hour after just three bites. Just three and really it was two and a half. 

I could go on about how rude the service was an how inattentive the douche bag working the window was when I had too repeat my order three times (and once more after he had taken money since clearly that is all that is on these peoples minds) but by now you have heard straight truth from a very honest and normally noncritical local who once loved ET and have opted for El Farrolitos or just elsewhere, anywhere.  You have avoided some nasty HB and Nausea and you're better off for it.  I am broker and sicker than I was $7 ago and saddened by this incredible culinary loss.
author: Patrick V.

description:
still the BEST taco...however, I was there last night and BEWARE ---- Best Buy will give you a ticket if you don't go in the store and buy something. 

Beast Buy's security guy patrols the parking lot and when he sees that you're going to the taco truck, he will pull out his thick pad of paper that looks like the ticket pad the SFPD traffic pulls out to give you a ticket. He will then ask you "how much is the taco? $78?" then proceeds to give a you a ticket....oh, by the way, he says this with so much conviction since y'know...he's big, tall and all that.  

I actually did not get a ticket since I went in the store to buy Timberlake's CD (I spotted the big guy looking around and figured what he was doing). But, the guy behind me wasn't so lucky. I honestly don't know if he got a ticket or not. 
But, beware of the beast guy --- oh, sorry, best buy's new parking policy.

El Tonayese STILLL has the best tacos, even though they always run out of radishes every time I visit.
author: Jo'an R.

description:
Definitely filled the need for spicy al pastor taco cravings, though three tacos did not seem like enough afterward. At $1.75 a pop, it's cheaper than at the taquerias themselves. Next time, I'm getting four. They give you the tacos on a paper plate with limes and pickled peppers. No plate cover unless you ask for one, then it's a foil. Cold water bottles are $1 a pop. Outdoor seating. haha.

Quickest route going towards 80E/Hwy101N is to take a left at the Vermont St exit, get to 16th St and turn right at Harrison St. Then look for the Best Buy and park there. It's also where to wash hands before/after - and also to browse their DVDs section so it then becomes a legit stop-in.

Taco trucks map y'all (http://www.yumtacos.com/).
author: Peter L.

description: I will gladly change my review  once this is figured out. I love these guys and the food but today I handed the guy my money, he handed my change back and then grabbed the tortilla and started making my food. Did not wash hands or even run them under water between cash and food handling. Sorry guys
author: Captain Muffin D.

description:
I'm so pissed off that this truck was on check please bay area. I can just imagine every little wannabe is going to want to come here now and the lines will start getting outrageous. 

Please, if you ever, I mean ever go on check please, never give away places like this. Select a popular and proper little sit down restaurant and leave the hole-in-the-wall, local and neighbor joints to word of mouth knowledge only, or at most yelp. Don't spread it on tv; even if it is local tv.

Best taco truck in the SF area. Compares favorably to LA taco trucks. End of story.
author: Dom L.

description:
OMG!, what can I say, we had one of their trucks come to the house for a family reunion/block party.  It was a hit from the get go.  The staff arrived on time and were ready for business.
There was a steady procession of the family lining up for seconds and thirds.
I would highly recommend them for your next event.
author: don b.

description: I love how they marinate their carne asada here. It's very unique compared to other places. The portion of the burrito is smaller than other places but each bite is pure bliss. Wish there was place to sit because I don't always come here with in car. They take credit card so that's a relief compared to other taco trucks I've been to.
author: Mark C.

description:
I love their tacos here! 

I've been coming here ever since the whole food truck become a craze, and their tacos are on point BUT... I just came here the other day.. I'm sad that they skimp on the meat. They gave less meat then before.. and I was a little disappointed. BUT IT STILL TASTE SO GOOD! ... If they are to give out so little meat, then I definitely think they should lower the price. Just saying!
author: Lianne D.

description: Use to come here all the time but never have them a review.  I think I would have given them 4-stars back in the day.  Nowadays...they get 2-stars.  Why?  No lingua!!  WTF!!  They use to have beef tongue...but not no more.
author: Patrick C.

description:
My neighbors had El Tonayense cater a neighborhood reception for their wedding.  Nice of them to do that.  And the truck arrived right on time and the guys inside were ready to rock and roll.  

They got the food out in good time and everyone enjoyed themselves.

Now in all honesty, the food was only OK.  Nothing special.  Certainly not better than or the equal of what you can get in many restaurants.  

But for a truck, it was quite good.
author: David D.

description:
Why not grab some tacos when buying a stereo system at Best Buy that is more expensive than your beat up, do-it-yourself-tinted car?  Someone sure saw that market opportunity!  If the parking lot ambiance doesn't suit you, trying noshing in front of the doggie play area a t the Wag Hotel... they are likely fans of this truck too.

Tacos: Each taco is simply made with two small corn tortillas (from a bag, not freshly pressed), the meat filling and a large glob of salsa that includes the obligatory cilantro and onions.  Relatively inexpensive for the neighborhood, you can try a wide variety for under $10.

Carne Asada: Well marinated and flavorful.  Appropriate crisp factor given that is grilled.

Carnitas: Could stand to be crispier.  Modest flavoring, a tad bland so the fattiness taste dominated.

Al Pastor: On par.  Good texture like the carne asada, but with a lot more spices!

Pollo: Shockingly one of my favorites despite chicken tending to be more boring.  Whatever they are stewing this in sure is working!

Pollo Asado: My only yuck!  The chicken was soft and rubbery with no signs of charring.  The marinade was weak or non-existent.  Dark meat is just not so tasty on its own.
author: Adam B.

description:
My favorite taco truck in the city, hands down. I always hunt it down parked outside Best Buy and do a Foods Co run when I need groceries =).

Great selection for tacos, feel adventurous and try an organ like Tongue (Lengua) or Tripe (Tripitas) etc...They make for excellent tacos and taste similar to the tradition beef or chicken one gets accustomed to. 

I do my best to limit myself to 3 tacos at most *cries*, because I know my gluttonous self could consume way more if given the opportunity. 

Wait time shouldn't be ridiculous, as orders are made pretty quickly. 

Grab some Horchata and I'm hunkering down for a great meal. No problem standing as I want to eat my food as soon as it comes off the grill. I've had their burritos, and tortas, but tacos is my guilty pleasure here.

Parking is easy if you decide to park in the Best Buy parking lot and sneak off to El Tonyanese. I don't get full here, but these quick bites of food really make me happy. It hurts when they run out of something, so be diligent if you see this truck and get in line!
author: Casey L.

description: Had a super Al pastor burrito today. Very tasty overall. It was more "saucey" inside than anything. Not a lot of meaty chunks. It was packed with flavor nevertheless and definitely was not bad. My only complaint would be that the burrito was kinda small. It was not filling. That's not really a bad thing either. Next time ill get a few tacos on the side. But overall good taste and good ingredients. If I'm around ill be back.
author: Mario W.

description:
im officially addicted to this truck. CASH ONLY 
 it is super close to the Soma Street food which i intend on going to all the time but i always end up here instead.
 the carne asada tacos with the salsa verde are the best although i have yet to try a burrito.

but these tacos are as good as the man that comes to my house for birthdays and family reunions if not better

the staff is always super friendly even when it is hot as hell outside and probably ten times hotter inside that truck.
author: Adriana L.

description:
The name just rolls of your tongue, doesn't it?

For starters, the menu is a little vague.  It lists only a selection of fillers for your items.  No prices.  The truck says "burritos", "tacos" and "tortas" so I presume you can get any of the fillers for those 3 options.  There is also no indication of what comes with any of them... I decided to just go with the flow and see what I would end up with. Oh, the anticipation!

Did I mention that the list of fillers include "head and cheek", "tongue", and "tripes"?  Um... giddy up, Silver!  C'mon Tonto... olé!

After noting that the truck was spotless inside and asking how much for a taco ($2), I ordered a sampler of 4 tacos:

The beef in my Asada taco was a little rubbery... did I order tongue by mistake?
The Al Pastor taco was tasty... pretty spicy.
The Carnitas taco was also tasty and juicy... pretty spicy.  Ding, ding, ding!
The chicken kibbles on my Pollo Asado taco were dry and blah.

Each of them came with some cooked onions, a bit of cilantro and there was a lime wedge on the plate.  I noted that another guy got two lime wedges on his plate of 3 tacos, but I only got one on my plate of 4. What gives?

I'm still a little hungry.

Here's the kicker: After I ordered my sampler, I wondered how I would ever be sure to receive what I ordered... the guy didn't take my name.  There were already about 15 people waiting for their orders.  Hmmm... how was this going to work? Well, there was lots of confusion.  The guy in the truck just barks out the item that's ready at any given moment.  It's up to you to remember what you ordered, translate the accent and battle it out with anyone else who might have ordered the same thing or something that sounds similar with that accent.  There were a couple of scuffles, but no fists flew.  One girl beside me wondered what she had ordered, 10 minutes after the fact.  You're on your own, kemosabe.
author: John D.

description: LOVE this place. I alwasy get their Lengua super burritos, though everything seems to be good there. One of my favorite 'taquerias'.
author: Bass T.

description:
I'm a huge burrito snob.  This taco truck's burritos are severely lacking.  The grilled chicken here is at the absolute bottom of the list for taquerias, even below El Balazo and Zona Rosa on haight, which I consider average at best.   The burritos at this taco truck just seem cheap and bland compared to just about anywhere else.  Basic chicken filling and that's about it.   Once I even had a gross purplish-bluish vein.  Plus the chicken itself is somehow prepared differently than any other Mexican joint in the city and not in a good way.

However the tacos here are pretty damn tasty.  I get the pork tacos and am very happy with them.  Why can't they put the same quality and care into their burritos?

In case you're wondering, burritos I'd consider great are El Burrito Express on Divisadero, Cancun and Pancho Villa.
author: Scott W.

description:
2 STARS for the good laugh I had....

Lady in back of me: Give me 2 tongue tacos and 2 steak tacos

Male employee: No more lengua.

Lady in back of me: F***, no more tongue!?!? WTF, what else taste like tongue--what you got?

Employee: Cabeza

Lady:  WTF is that?

Employee: Head

Lady: Tongue taste like heads? What kinda head...you mean head or head, heads?

Employee: Head

Lady: Heads....heads?

Employee: No Maam, not that kind of head.

Lady: F***, I'm so f****** EMBARASSED. F****, here's your money, just give me my damn tacos,

Yah, so they were out of lengua, so I opted for the tripe burrito. Except, I never knew tripe tasted like burnt carnitas? Ok, probably there was a language barrier. But, still the carnitas was not good...it was dry/brunt and the burrito was more rice and beans than anything.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
The best chicken tacos and horchata. I know horchata and this place has the good stuff.  If you wait until late night, you wont get any. 

I get the same thing every time I go so I cant report on much else.  However, both the mild and the spicy chicken tacos are bomb!

My date and I can get 4 tacos and 2 horchata/ horchatas (what's the plural for horchata, anyway?) for about $10 too.  

Love it!
author: C S.

description:
My favorite taco truck!!

-Al Pastor Spicy Tacos $1.75 
(add guacamole & sour cream)

-Coke in a bottle or a Mandarin Jarritos
author: Stacey L.

description:
After a pretty ridiculously long walk from deep in the confines of the Mission, I made my way to Best Buy to return some piece of hardware or another... After stepping out, and in the mood for a snack, I decided to step up to the truck and check it out. Pick the type of meat (anything from chicken to carnitas, tripe to vegetarian.) Pick the vehicle in which you will consume said meat in --- tortas, quesadillas, tacos, burritos... And you are set!

I wasn't terrible hungry, so I opted for a Carnitas taco, as well as an Al Pastor... Tacos were 1.75 each, it included a spicy pickle pepper for each also (pickled peppers are pretty much my weakness...) Tacos come with 2 tortillas each so that they dont disintegrate from the juicyness of the meat + the lime juice you squeeze over it from the provided lime wedges.

The tacos were unbelievably delicious, and perfect portable, walking size. Ended up eating them as I walked home. They meats were super juicy (especially the al pastor!) The pickled pepper brought everything together for me. If it wasn't for that, i would have probably felt it was a quarter too much for a taco... But then again --- I am a sucked for pickled peppers...
author: Mike V.

description:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eyM4xIr6Da0

I thoughts it was good! The price was definitely right. I walked there on my lunch break and for one....it felt good to get off my butt and walk to lunch and secondly there's something ritual about standing outside and eating Mexican style street tacos. I also liked the fact that they had mexican coke! The only reason I didn't go with 5 stars is because they don't have refried beans. Oh well, sometimes San Francisco is too healthy for it's own good ;-).
author: Sandy P.

description:
It is a truck. They sell tacos and burritos. It is a truck with a clean kitchen, the city says so.

Not much to report here except that I had two tacos, and while the smoky spicy stewing sauce was nice on the chicken, it completely masked the flavor of the carnitas. That is not a good thing, as I love the flavor of pork.
author: Gwynnie P.

description: Wow! I just had this today and it was totally delicious. The tacos just ooze flavor left and right. Tried the Asada, Pollo Asado, and Al Pastor. Loved the Al Pastor the most, but the other two were certainly close.
author: Richard K.

description:
Fantastic tacos emanate from this humble taco truck parked by Best Buy.  Their signature smoky, spicy red salsa makes the difference.  And their soft tacos have just the essentials: corn tortillas, meat, chopped onions, cilantro and a wedge of lime.  The menu is simple (tacos, burritos, tortas, chips) but there are plenty of meat options and you can get veggie tacos too.  They have drinks too (soda, water, horchata).

I had three tacos ($1.75 each).  The two soft corn tortillas per taco make these easy to fold and eat.  

* Neck - I thought this would be stringy (and it was).  It's like pulled pork.   Flavorful, seasoned well but fattier than I expected.    
* Grilled chicken - Chunks have great grilled flavor and they're not too large and not too small.  Delicious.  
* Head and cheek - My least favorite because the head and cheek meat was bland - reminded me of intestines but it comes in soft chunks.  I think any taco would taste great with their salsa, onions, cilantro and lime juice though.

You can get brains, tripe, tongue, al pastor, and carnitas too.  I like trying unusual cuts and my favorite (out of head & cheek, neck, tripe, brains & tongue) is lengua (tongue), followed by the neck.  I haven't tried brains and tongue here though.  Next time I'll get those tacos with extra cilantro.  Yum.  

I've also overcome my fear of the humble taco truck, so thank you El Tonayense.
author: Lolia S.

description:
I have made about 10 trips to Best Buy in the last two weeks, and almost everytime, I am tempted to buy their amazing tacos de tripas. Soooooo good! The red salsa is too hot and I usually like spicyness, so I suggest the mild sauce.
The tacos de carne asada are okay..get other ones preferably. 
I haven't even checked out the tortas, but I will soon.
They park always in the middle of Best Buy and OfficeMaxx, so if you are in the area...check it out! Tacos are only $1.75, I believe.
author: Analleli G.

description: Simply amazing tacos. Their spicy sauce is great. Don't skip over this place because it's a food truck; these are literally the best tacos I've ever had in both Norcal and Socal. Would highly recommend this place to anyone that loves Mexican Food
author: Geoffrey H.

description:
Usually burritos are a bit disappointing, due to dry meat. 
My first bite of an El Tonayense burrito made my mouth do a double take (read as bite!).  My tongue could not believe it's luck!  A super moist burrito, with a little spice, not too much, like I asked.  By far, this was the best burrito I have ever had; experienced at Carnaval 2010.  They also, during the festival, after the parade, were friendly while whipping out the food surprisingly fast.  This past Carnaval 2011, I didn't mess around, heading straight to the El Tonayense Taco Truck!  Do the same, and your taste buds will dance around your mouth with joy!
author: Delicious B.

description: before this I liked this taco Truck.... Now... NOT NO MORE!!! Today my Mom ( 60 years old with the heart of a saint) had an altercation with an employee of the truck. She wasn't aware that she took the parking spot that he had planned to take and once she pulled into the parking spot he told her to move and if she didn't he would hit her car. After the threat, my mom tried compramising so that they would both fit in the space and he started ramming my Mom's car, while she was in it, with the taco truck!!!! WHAT!? Who does that! Thank God my Mom is OK- he hit her car so bad that the front grill came off. PLEASE DO NOT SUPPORT THIS TRUCK!!
author: Pauline J.

description: I ordered a steak burrito and a chicken burrito. Worst burritos I've ever seen.  Barely can taste any beef, and barely any chicken. It was like the meats were all grind up with the mushy beans. Very disappointed with the quality.  So I'm not sure what's the fuss about it being the best from other reviewers??? Am I missing something?  And the price isn't great either.
author: Logan Y.

description:
Great food.. They have some of the best pollo asado in the city.. and I've tried a lot of places, like Taqueria Cancun (both of them), all 3 El Farolitos, Guadalajara, Pancho Villa, La Taqueria, El Faro near O'Connell, and a bunch of other spots.

This place has, over the years, become my favorite place to go for Mexican food..  Why? The line isn't anywhere near as long as the taquerias in the Mission that are now crowded with nothing but hipsters. There's always parking thanks to the Best Buy. And it's pretty centrally located and close to the freeway. So when you have a car and you're hungry, it's one of the fastest places to get Mexican food.
author: Steve R.

description:
Meh. 

I hit the El Tonayense Truck at Off the Grid a couple of weeks ago and my tacos were pretty lackluster, both the chicken and pork tasted identical. I'm not sure if we got the second string or what but since I've heard nothing but raves about the truck that parks outside Best Buy, I was definitely disappointed.

Cheap enough that I'll give them another shot but it'll definitely be at their flagship truck on Harrison.
author: phil h.

description: Overrated and unimpressed. Had the tacos al pastor and it wasn't that great. Too much green sauce on top, and the pork, although has pretty decent flavor, was too watery/liquidy.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
I'm not easy to please when it comes to tacos. And since I've moved to San Francisco from LA a few months ago, it's been a sad time for Mexican food. I've had my fill of Mission mexican food and whatnot but nothing really did it. Until I paid El Tonayense a visit. 
I thoroughly enjoyed my carne asada and al pastor tacos, devouring both and washing it down with a Coke. The meat was actually tasty and cooked well and the tacos had the right amount of everything. It was ALMOST like I was back in LA...Definitely worth the line.
author: Lisa K.

description:
My review is for the truck on 17th and Harrison.

I've been getting burritos from this truck for a few years now, they've never been great, but at least the service was good and they could build a consistant slab.

Three times in a row now they've given me grilled chicken even though it wasn't what I ordered. I asked the new gumpy guy if he was putting grilled chicken on my burrito while watching him put grilled chicken on my burrito. He said, nope. First bite I got a mouth full of rubbery, nubby, burnt, dry chicken parts and a tiny bone, aka. Grilled Chicken. 

The worst part is, I can generally deal with wrong meats on my burrito, I actually like their pork, but their grilled chicken is the worst in the business. 

So now I'm writing while picking cartilage out my burrito and teeth..
author: Jeff C.

description: Tacos in the shadow of a Best Buy - delicious.  Nothing fancy here...just straight up meat and tortilla, a sprig of veg and a little sauce.  Spicy is a bit spicy.  Mexican cokes wash it all down nicely.
author: David S.

description: Their tacos are pretty good!!! We tried different types of the beef tacos. I enjoyed the Beef tripe taco the most because the taco guy made it crispy for us! Thank you!
author: Anji W.

description:
It's always been a dream of mine to have a party catered by an El Tonayense truck, with free flowing tacos and carnitas and chips and salsa.   Ahhh, someday.

So we stopped here for a quick bite last week- 2 tacos and a burrito to share in the Best Buy parking lot.  The tacos were amazing with tons of lime juice and perfectly cooked carnitas.  The carne asada burrito was great too...until my boyfriend took a bite, coughed, and proceeded to pull out a loooong hair from the innards of the burrito.  

Puke.  But we still finished the burrito because it was too good to throw away.  Is that gross?   And I'd still come back, at least for the tacos.
author: Joanne G.

description:
This review is purely for hiring a taco truck for catering a party, I haven't eaten at the trucks themselves nor do I plan to.

If I could give zero stars I would.

My friend likes the taco truck idea, and keeps hiring El Tonayense to cater his parties, so I've had their food for several years now.

I have to believe the catered menu is a small subset of what is available on the street, and it is garbage. Bland tacos, bland rice, bland meat, bland everything, and limited selections. Example: they will make you a nice big cheesy quesadilla, but there's no salsa. Seriously.

"Can I get some salsa with this?"
"We don't have salsa."

Why of course you don't, silly me for asking if a Mexican taco truck has salsa.

"How about guacamole then?"
"I'll put some on for you."
(obviously wants to control the portion)
"I'd rather have it on the side."

He squirts some dubious green liquid from a plastic bottle into a Solo cup, and I realize that not only does he want to control the portion, but he doesn't want me to actually see the "guacamole" by itself. Why? Because it's absolutely disgusting. Flavorless green cream product is a more apt description, and there may have been one avocado per gallon of fatty cream, but the rest was food coloring.

No black beans either.

So, no salsas at all, no black beans, fake guacamole, and for this they charge $650 for 3 hours. 30ish people at the party, let's say average tab $8, that's a pretty good profit. Good enough to make some salsa, cook some beans, and slice a few avocados.

Oh, and to top it off, the cooks kept asking for beers from our stash!
Un-fricking-believable.

I wouldn't ever hire these people: incredibly mediocre food, expensive, lack of normal expected goes-withs, and furthermore they want to drink on your dime.
author: Rob C.

description: This taco truck truly is as good as it gets when it comes to serving meat tacos and burritos. The Pastor Tacos are so juicy and delicious, providing just the right amount of flavor for you to be standing there ordering one after the other. The gentlemen working the truck are always friendly and there is an assortment of canned and bottled drinks aside as well. I have started coming here over my usual places and well, I guess you can say this is my regular taco spot now. You must check it, it's worth the trip.
author: Diego A.

description:
don't know if this is the appropriate thread for the el tonayense truck parked at 16th & shotwell.

menu: tacos, burritos, tortas, 10 kinds of meats available plus vegetarian. no prices listed anywheres.

there wasn't much of a line so i ordered an asada burrito (6). surprised burrito price exceeded even some shop on mission (4.99) and equalled many shops on 16th st.

frijoles refritos:
-burrito larger than regular,  no salsa, chips, jalepen0s given.
-meat, onion, fluffy rice, beans, and salsa. taste was ok not great.
-cashier also made burritos by hand, not sure if he used gloves at any time.
-semifast, friendly service.
-saw health score of 100 posted on taco truck.
-will probably repeat, other times burrito was great and cheaper.
author: Victor G.

description: The best Mexican in SF. No contest. Cheap, greasy, delicious. None of that Whole Foods mentality here, just real street Mexican. Al Pastor will blow ya dick off.
author: Jordan d.

description:
My first taco truck experience.  I had heard about this truck and passed it on my way back from paying for a parking violation, so I had to stop (after I pretended to go into Best Buy so the parking lot gestapo wouldn't yell at me).

They weren't the absolute best tacos I've ever had, but they were tasty, the ingredients were fresh, and the tab for two tacos and a large horchata was only $4.50!  Their tacos are definitely on the smaller side - I thought about going back for a third, but figured I'd save room for next time.
author: dan s.

description:
Another recommendation from Check Please. You'd think I'd couldn't find anything myself!

I tried two items (tacos and super burrito) so far on different days and I'm a fan! Their Carne Asada and Al Pastor meats are very good. Next to try is the Pollo Asado. Unfortunately, they ran out by the time I would typically get there (6:30pm). And being a "taco truck" and all, I'm very glad that they're even still there that late.

So, this'll be my burrito stop on my way home now.
author: Ed L.

description:
Who am I to argue with Michelin? Is it possible that some of the best carne asada is to be found parked outside of a Best Buy? 

Reading the news clippings pasted in the window of this colorful truck, I find out that foodies from near and far trek to this specific taco truck for their Mexican food fixes. I tried the things that I traditionally judge Mexican restaurants by: al pastor burrito, carne asada quesadilla, a couple of tacos (carnitas), and an agua fresca (pineapple). The al pastor burrito was good, although it really kind of just tasted like a chorizo burrito. But I guess that's the flavor profile for the al pastor. The quesadilla was average. The cilantro salsa sauce was really good, but the quality of the meat was just 'eh', and I think they either left out the sour cream and guac from my super quesadilla or they put so little in that it was non-existent. The agua fresca wasn't that great, either. 

Overall, not bad, but given all the other fabulous choices that you have in the Mission just a few blocks away, I'd have to opt for one of those. But hey, at least you can just park in the Best Buy lot for this taco truck and the service was pretty quick.
author: Saunders C.

description: 5 stars for the meat, I just think every other element of my burrito brought down the quality. The meat is so juicy and flavorful, it is definitely something you have to try on your way out of Best Buy.
author: Caitlin H.

description: BPM made a special request to feed the entire staff, and the tacos was 100% awesome...Must bring them back for 2nds...
author: Alex H.

description:
As some of the previous reviews have stated, the burritos here can be iffy. However, this isn't a burrito truck, this is a taco truck! Their tacos cannot be beat. 

And yes, I would like this truck at my party!
author: Ian P.

description:
THIS REVIEW IS ONLY FOR THE TACOS!

Holy Moly!!! those are some good tacos!!


thats it...go buy them now!

p.s. i go to the bestbuy at harrison just to get these tacos
And im a target shopper...FML LOL
author: Eric S.

description:
I never leave hungry when visiting the Taco Truck.. You're great! don't ever change.

This is the BEST Mexican joint in SF!!
author: Emily L.

description:
Quick.  Cheap.  Good.  Taco's are the the star.  Pork.  Spicy.  radishes on the side. peppers.  So good.

Burritos are good.  Decent size.  Not oversized.  Fresh.  Juicy.  

Always a good stop for a quick and good lunch.
author: Clifford S.

description:
This is for the Tonayense that sits outside the SOMA Best Buy (Harrison & Duboce). 

People are giving these guys bad marks based on burrito reviews. WRONG. You need to be getting the TORTAS. It's a rookie mistake and I completely understand. I've been in that boat before but quickly learned what's up.

I can always count on these guys for a solid, quick torta fix. In fact, I only count on THESE guys for my torta fix. I've tried a handful of other taquerias' tortas and they just don't hold up - missing the chopped up tasty carne asada (most places will give you a "cold cut" style piece of meat), the tasty, toasted bread and the green sauce. Oh my lordy, the green sauce...

The tacos also look insanely good though I've never had enough inner strength to pass up the torta to give the taco a proper go. 


I also want to add that you can't beat the parking situation - the huge Best Buy parking lot.


WARNING: The guys behind the plexi-glass window will swear up and down to you that they're there until 9pm every night but if you're feening for that mexican silver bullet of goodness and the time is closing in on 830pm, you should be formulating a plan B. I speak from experience.
author: Kenneth L.

description:
Benny you are making me fat!  My ass is getting bigger, and people keep asking me if I'm pregnant.  Well I guess that's what happens when you eat three tacos twice a week, but it is totally worth it.

First of all it's cheap!  $1.75 per taco and they have a lot to choose from.  Plus parking is a breeze (I usually park in Best Buy if I can't find one on the street shhh...).  I always get the two  al pastor and a carne asada taco.  Both are great.  I have tried the tripe, tongue, and head and cheek taco but it really wasn't my cup tea.  My boyfriend however, ALWAYS gets 4 tripe tacos.  Yes, people think he is with child as well...

Come try out this place.  It is SUPER clean, and I see the guys wash their hands all the time.  Trust you will love it.
author: Lyly P.

description: Best taco truck in the city!!! They have a groupon for this place however you need to print out the groupon to bring in rather than claim it on your phone. Despite this one inconvenience, I still give it a 5 star rating.
author: Krystle A.

description: Steak burrito hit the spot!!! Just need to remember next time to order extra steak... Felt like there wasn't much meat other than that it was hella good!
author: Catherine K.

description: I LOVE this taco truck. I always get the chicken tacos, spicy. The chicken is moist and the flavor is great. It can get busy but the line and service moves quick!
author: Ashley N.

description:
Me:  How was your weekend?

Co-worker:  I ate El Tonayense tacos.

Me:  Oooh.  I heard they're good.

Co-worker:  When we got there, a guy was eating his taco.  He looked up at his friend, smiled, and said, "felicidad."

Me:  Wow, that must be some good tacos.

Co-worker:  Oh, they were.

[Fast forward two weeks]

Me:  Felicidad.
author: Tara C.

description: If El Farolito was a truck. You can't go wrong with any of the selections here. I really wish they weren't all the way out near the Best Buy otherwise I would come here and sample the rest of their meats. A must-try.
author: Z L.

description: I love El Tonayense. I've been feeling lately that the true home of the taco truck is LA. Tonayense delivers everything in the right portions: good tortillas, decent meat, pico de gallo, all with a dash of "deliciously sketchy" and low prices to go with it. It's a big chain now, though, but a good one if you ask me. Try their cabeza if you haven't had it before.
author: Josh K.

description:
Edit: I've had it with these clowns.

I stopped by yesterday for a no-meat burrito, for which I was charged NINE DOLLARS.  

This is idiotic.  Nine dollars for a no-meat burrito is already more than just about any restaurant in SF charges (much less a TRUCK).  But what kind of restaurant charges the exact same price for a burrito with just rice, beans, cheese and guacamole, as they do for one that *also* has chopped steak, salsa, etc.?  I doubt very much that there's a single restaurant anywhere that does that.  But El Tonayense apparently thinks it's special enough to rip-off its vegetarian customers.  

I've had probably 35-40 burritos from El Tonayense over the past 9 years and I have repeatedly (and politely) raised the question of why they're charging the same for a burrito *without* meat as for one *with* meat, and the answers I've gotten have been pretty much "the owner sets the prices" (and of course, the owner isn't in the truck to be questioned).  Last night was the last straw.  

If you went to a taqueria, ordered a steak burrito and requested double the amount of steak, do you think that the extra would be free?  Of course not!  Steak is by far the most expensive ingredient in such a burrito, and they'd charge probably 30-40% extra to double it.  But going in the opposite direction -- having zero meat -- they charge the same?  Fuck that!

Furthermore, El Tonayense doesn't have the overhead of a storefront taqueria.  It's just a truck, with two employees and no amenities like seating, bathrooms, etc., and no extras like chips.  My go-to taqueria -- El Burrito Express in Lower Pacific Heights -- has to pay expensive rent, has a large dining room, a crew of 3-6 employees at any one time, as well as much higher utility costs, insurance, and even a beer and wine license!  And frankly, their meatless burritos are better than El Tonayense -- and they give free chips.  And yet El Burrito Express charges $6.50 for their meatless burrito, and is still making a good enough profit to have just completely remodeled their restaurant, and to have been in business there for more than 20 years!  

The old saying goes "Fool me once, shame on you.  Fool me twice, shame on me."  Well, El Tonayense fooled me for 9 years with their price-gouging, but they fooled me for the last time.
author: Curran H.

description: Very very good food simple menu cheap prices great service.  Will b back.
author: George E.

description: Nice! Only 7 bucks for a cabeza super burrito. And the guy was fast, efficient and didn't frown on me when I just wanted to charge it since I had no cash but this truck looked really good. Unfortunately it was hours later before I had the chance to eat the burrito and by then it was so cold but still tasty. For a super burrito it wasn't extremely loaded it had just enough. The cabeza was no over cooked and dry like it sat out all day yesterday and today. The rice was a little  under cooked for my taste but still overall it was A-Okay.
author: Ms. T.

description:
Delicious al pastor tacos, for $1.75 each.  You get a good amount of meat on the taco, so two is usually enough to make you stuffed!  The horchata is also pretty good.    

Great meal if you're on a budget!  Be prepared to eat on the sidewalk or the parking lot of BB.  Yum Yum Yum!
author: Cynthia H.

description: The best reason to go to Best Buy in San Francisco might just be there proximity to the El Tonayense Taco Truck. Dirt cheap tacos with a lot of flavor. Hard to distinguish one protein from another, but it's good just the same. Park at Best Buy, eat in your car.
author: Dave B.

description:
The Al Pastor tacos are pretty good. They could do a bit better by making the tortillas fresh. I think it would really up the ante on their tacos. 

The meat is decent - flavorful, tender, full of spices. It's just really greasy, and I don't know why. I've had Al Pastor tacos from a variety of places and they never seem as greasy as El Tonayense's. It's alright though - a little grease never did any harm. If anything, it adds another element of flavor.
author: Amanda D.

description: It was the most disappointing visit.  I expected more since it has high reviews.  When I visited, the server was rude and on the phone the whole time he helped us.  I asked a simple question which he looked unhappy to answer.  I guess because I am disrupting his phone conversation.  Most importantly, the food was not edible.  It was soggy and disgusting.
author: Aban E.

description:
Instant Gratification

Sometimes I just want a small, but delicious bite to eat that doesn't fill the tank and break the bank.  El Tonayense carne asada and lengua tacos fit the bill.

Loaded with a few bites of meat, onions, cilanto and garnished with radish and lime, Tonayense's tacos pack a flavorful punch and can be eaten in just a few bites!  That's what I call good eats!

$1.75 for a taco.
author: Jane L.

description: What a great place and area to be at for the weekend! Great place for kids, and yummy food!! Nice to know this is what I will be coming back too every weekend!
author: A M.

description:
Two thumbs way up for seriously tasty tacos and seriously cheap too.  Long before the city was inundated by tweeting street food carts, there was El Tonayense.  My favorite location is at 14th and Harrison.  This taco truck is ever dependable.

http://blog.junbelen.com/2009/11/19/el-tonayenses-tasty-street-tacos/
author: Jun B.

description:
El Tonayense is one of my favorite lunch destinations. It serves up great tacos and burritos with fast and friendly service, the latter remarkable considering they're serving it up from a truck.

They serve plenty variety of meat here and if you're adventurous in your choices, this is my list in descending order: 1) Neck (Buche), 2) Tripes (Tripitas), 3) Tongue (Lengua), 4) Head & Cheek (Cabeza); but they're all gorgeous and I gotta have them all. I've never had any of their 'normal' meat so I can't comment on them.

If it is your first time eating here, I recommend that you go for the taco, as it is much smaller than the burrito and you should sample one of each meat. Once you're more of a veteran, then maybe you can focus and and get the burrito, with your favorite meat.

The tacos portion are kinda small though. I usually order them with single tortilla skin and I can chow down 1 taco in just 2 bites. I think I'd need 10 tacos to feed me completely! But the burrito is huge and just 1 order should be enough.

And one last thing to say, if it's not late at night and you're craving for some tacos/burrito, head to this place first and not that over-rated El Farolito, you will not regret it.
author: Handoyo S.

description:
I've heard about the famous taco truck for the past 2 years, but had yet to stumble upon it. Finally, while walking with my roommate, we came across the taco truck and were overcome with excitement! If there is one cuisine I am passionate about it is Mexican food.

I got carne asada tacos and let me tell you they were some of the best tacos I have had. I am a very picky eater, especially when it comes to Mexican food. I use to think you could not get quality food from a taco truck but Tonayense changed my opinion. The guy who serves the food is super friendly too.

Tonayense is an SF treat!
author: Surge C.

description:
The best taco truck in San Francisco. It's a bold statement, but in my opinion, it's really true. This particular el tonayense truck is parked outside the Best Buy on the SOMA/Mission border. One of the great things about it (besides the food) is how it brings local SF flavor to something as universally common as a Best Buy. I love the juxtaposition.

Anyways, the food is why you go here. Their al pastor tacos, at $1.50 each, are an amazing steal and seriously are some of the best mexican food in northern california. It's all fresh, it's all made-to-order, and it's unbelievably clean. This truck receives 100% on the annual health inspection every single year...that's far more sanitary than the majority of fancy expensive places in this town. 

The al pastor is the show-stealer for me, but they also do chicken, carne asada, and the more exotix lengua (tongue) and cabeza (head). You can also get Jarritos or Mexican Coke in glass bottles, which is always a plus. Parking is easy because you can park in the huge Best Buy lot. It's close the freeway and covenient. 

It's the perfect taco truck.
author: Tolga E.

description:
What can I say?
Hot day, two tacos, some spicy pickled jalapenos, -$3.50 in the wallet and 5 fingers to lick.
Not bad, not bad.
Loved the sauce for the carnitas and the piquant green sauce for the carne asada. Smacky good!
author: Dario B.

description:
Great chain of taco trucks. The asada burrito is one of the best in San Francisco. Their hot salsa is tough to beat.

The tacos are good for SF but still not on caliber with LA trucks

7 bucks for a super asada burrito is a bit much for a truck
author: James B.

description: One of the best taco trucks in the city!  Even better than some dine-in taquerias!
author: Lloyd A.

description:
Pretty straight forward review. If you want a delicious burrito and fast...El Tonanyense is clean, the guys in the truck are nice and the burritos are pretty delicious. The vegetarian burrito is zesty and addictive. There are weeks when I eat here day after day and never regret it afterwards. I do fall into a burrito coma afterwards but thats to be expected. 

If you like Tongue, brains, cheek or head...My friends that eat parts tell me thats good too.
author: Go Cat Go G.

description: Had a chicken quesidilla from this truck during lunch nearby Mission & 16th.  It cost around $6.50 and was humongous in size and very tasty. They had this greenish looking saucy that was a little spicy, but not too overpowering.  They have a variety of meat to choose from like lengua (cow tongue), buche (stomach), asada, grilled chicken, etc.  Basically you choose a type of meat and decide whether you want tortas, tacos, burritos, or quesidillas from here. Overall, a pretty good Mexican place for food, but don't come here if you're on a diet.  Also, CASH ONLY.
author: Patty O.

description:
Meh. Unfortunately I won't be coming back.  For some reason I have heard loads of good things about this taco truck but my beef burrito was just mediocre.  I ordered the beef burrito, spicy, with no cheese or sour cream.  I forgot to say no beans because the beans inside my burrito was huge! Gross. 

The super burrito is actually a really skinny burrito someone my size (5'1 110 lbs) can easily polish off.  It was also really wet inside.  I like my guac looking like guac - green and chunky.  This guac looked like it was mixed with sour cream because it was really watery and mostly a whitish color.

Texture of the beef was questionable.  It actually taste like ground beef.  Hardly any rice in the burrito too.  Definitely not spicy enough.

Overall, just ok.  For $6.50 you can definitely find a better burrito elsewhere. Not a truck I would go back to.  Service is quick though.  We got our food in under 5 minutes and there wasn't much of a line around noon time either.  Los Compadres taco truck on spear/folsom is way better.
author: Terry D.

description:
I saw this on KQED's CHECK PLEASE and happened to be in the neighborhood so I decided to try a beef (carne asada) burrito.  I asked if it came with cheese but he said that's only in the super burrito that also includes sour cream and avocado.  The super burrito was only 50 cents more but I didn't want the sour cream.  He then agreed to give me the "regular" burrito with cheese.

It came fast but when I bit into it, I found the burrito had very little filling and was almost 50% flour tortilla.  For the $6 price, I could have gotten a decent burrito almost anywhere in the Mission district.  Besides the small amount of filling, the meat was soooo salty I couldn't eat it.   It also wasn't good quality meat.  I'm use to getting chopped or shredded grilled steak when I order a carne asada burrito, not steamed ground beef.

This was a major disappointment.  They get two stars simply because the person who took my order was nice and accommodated my request for cheese with the "regular" burrito.  The food does not live up to the CHECK PLEASE hype.  If you want a good burrito, go to La Taqueria on Mission & 24th or El Toro on Valencia & 17th.  This taco truck sucks!
author: Jean L.

description:
This one is simple. Doesn't need a lot to explain it.

The tacos are great. They're not enormous California creations, they're just good little tacos. Salsas are great, and prices are right.

I've tried most of their fillings, and I order the tripitas almost exclusively. I love tripe, but only if it's done well (can be crispy or soft, depending on the cuisine) and this is my favorite crispy tripe - bar none.

In all the years I've been going, I've never had a problem with freshness or quality - as has been mentioned in other reviews. And FYI - San Francisco does inspect these vehicles and the one I visited most recently had a 94/100 rating posted in the window.

They prep all of the food in their taqueria on 24th St and deliver multiple times a day to their (several) trucks around the city.

If you don't like street food, don't go. You're standing around eating on the sidewalk with pigeons. If you can handle that, you're in for a treat.
author: Jeff B.

description:
I love the cabeza taco, real flavorful chunks of  cheek and flesh there.  My recent favorite however has been the regular al pastor torta.  They butter the bread for extra deadliness.  The servers are always nice too.

torta + horchata + best buy restrooms for washing my hands after all that spicy goodness = joy
author: Mia G.

description:
When I first hear "taco truck", I thought "food poisoning." I am glad to say, I am so very wrong. 

I've loved this place since I first tried the carne asada taco. It is absolutely delicious! The flavour is outstanding, and believe me, once you've finished your order, you'd want more. I am not surprised that it gained a Michelin recommendation. 

If you are by the neighbor hood, definitely stop by.
author: Bianca W.

description: Radical tacos!  Best Buy is lucky to have them out front because I've spent money in there just waiting for the taco line to die down.  And I've also been to the El Tonayense on 24th, and strangely the tacos were less delicious.
author: Paul M.

description: Seriously, what food truck puts out food like this? Perhaps I'm just a novice food truck eater, but I was expecting somewhat greasy and mostly sub-par food when we placed our order. I opted for two veggie tacos (under $2 each) and was shocked by how good these things were! Not greasy in the slightest -- corn tortilla, rice, beans and the perfect amount of spice. All around great order and a great little bit for lunch on the cheap!
author: Shannon E.

description:
My husband and I make excuses to go to Best Buy about twice a month, so we can actually hit up the taco truck that's parked on the street next to it. It took me a few visits to really appreciate this truck, but now my mouth waters whenever we're anywhere near the area. 

I've tried the carne asada, pollo, and carnitas, but my absolute favorite is the al pastor tacos - a perfect amount of spicy, tender pork complimented by fresh onion/cilantro relish and salsa verde, and a squirt of lime. I love how the juices drip down from the other end as I bite into them. 

Served on flimsy paper plates, we usually end up eating while standing on the sidewalk, but these tacos are so delish that we practically inhale them within five minutes anyway. Yum!
author: Amy H.

description:
Dropped by here after work yesterday.

Nothing spectacular about their burritos.  I love buche.  Their version definitely is spicier but that's about it.  I found it odd that it tasted meaty and lacked the intense porky flavor I'm familiar with. The buche I was introduced to by my friends is not from the neck as listed on their menu but the esophagus of the pig. 

I was a bit disappointed.  If you're in the neighborhood then drop by otherwise you can find better for just bit more change at a taqueria.
author: Sun T.

description: Even though half of my orders come back without the black beans I ask for, I still think they are the best burrito in town. So flavorful!
author: C S.

description:
AY CARAMBA!

This taco truck offers LOVE at first bite. 

I innocently made a trip to Best Buy, but felt myself falling deeper into love with every bite of my two carne asada street-sized tacos. $4.50 for two tacos and a soda. YUM. And who cares that it was 4:30pm, the perfect time for a taco snack!
author: Misha F.

description: Tasty food, prepared quickly, friendly service. Prices were steep for small portions of food.  Overall interesting but not the great experience everyone claims this is.
author: Sheva B.

description: Best tacos in town. Bottled and canned soda. Mexican coke. Try the quesadilla. Vegetarian friendly. Go after Rainbow.
author: SF I.

description: I'm generally a picky eater. So I was pleased when I could get the basic taco fare for a really cheap bill! Fast service and super delicious.
author: Cory M.

description: Okay, try the tripe here too.  *drool*
author: Fannie S.

description: El Tonayense catered the late-night snack for our wedding reception in SF 2 weeks ago, and they were a great addition to the event. They made the reservation process very easy and quick, even if last minute. Their carne asada and lengua tacos are our fave, but do not overlook their quesadillas (which are pricey but well-sized and worth it). Do a taste-test since they are consistently parked outside Best Buy in SF. There time-to-response could have been improved although they were undergoing a change in staffing at the time. Very reasonably priced and they are able to work late-night hours! Highly recommend.
author: Danessa L.

description: I was disappointed in my "super" veggie burrito. It was not super at all.  It was mostly lettuce with barely any of the more fun ingredients like guacamole. I don't even know what else was in there, very bland.  The horchata was yummy, very good.
author: Mark S.

description:
If you're someone who loves Mexican food...wait...if you're a human being who loves to eat, period, you owe yourself a trip to any one of El Tonayense's taco trucks in the city. 

The quantity and quality of reviews speaks for itself. They even proudly display their city health inspection score of 100. My 2 cents would tell you to make sure you get an Al Pastor (marinated pork) anything...taco, burrito, or maybe they'll even put a couple spoonfuls into a bowl...not a bad idea either. The asada and carnitas are also amazing. Their salsas and marinades are what really kick it up a notch and separate themselves from the pack. 

I recently was quoted by saying, "I think I could eat these tacos everyday of the week" and I'm willing to back up my talk. Won't you join me?
author: Jarrett T.

description:
Oh-My-GAWD! My favorite place for Tacos!
 I always order Al Pastor tacos with extra lemons on the side. Sooo good and so affordable. 
Im sure there are 3 but I always go to the one infront of Best Buy. 
The guys that work there are super cool. 
Pretty close to the ones I get in Los Angeles.
author: Nene D.

description:
taco thursdays!
taco thursdays!
taco thursdays at tonyanese!! 

actually, i could never remember the name.. but you know it's the taco truck parked right out of best buy! i always get the same thing.. carnitas tacos with mild sauce. i've also tried their spicy (red) sauce as well, but there's definitely more flavor with the mild green sauce. and from time to time, i like to mix it up with horchata. 

and 5 stars for the guys who work here who always gets our 6-different-tacos-with-extra-lime orders correctly. there's no better way to spend a thursday night!
author: Lina W.

description:
El Tonayense! We meet at last.

Your intoxicating perfume of meat and spice draws me close. I salivate and tremble with excitement as I barely get out the words lengua and pastor . . .

The wait, it's almost unbearable! Fortunately the burritos and tacos are flying out at a frenetic pace, and soon I have a plateful of your succulent seared flesh in my hands. Now, we dance.

It's a beautifully sculpted mound of meat drenched in salsa resting on supple tortillas. Sweetness gives way to heat, and the lengua crumbles tenderly. A couple more judicious bites and it's polished off. Poor taco didn't even have a chance to cool down. I move on to the pastor.

I give a quick squeeze of lime and rearrange my jalapeno slices. I devour luscious bits of pork in a maniacal frenzy. I try to savor the moment but all is powerless against my appetite as the tacos disappear from the plate. I recline in my seat, and I lick my fingers clean. That hit the spot.

Unfortunately taco love does not come cheap here, as $1.75 is on the high end even for a taqueria, let alone a taco truck. And I could do with less salsa. But I'm not complaining. This was so good, so very good.

While I'm still an El Paisano devotee (my first, won my heart), I'll never forget our sordid afternoon affair. Oh El Tonayense, we'll do this again!
author: Mike W.

description: I come here for the tacos. I will never find another taco better than this. I buy 3 at a time since they're small and delicious. Those guys are really nice. Not intimidating at all. One time he called me homie. :D
author: Chris L.

description:
IGNORE THE HYPE.  These are just OK tacos -- not bad, but not worth any Best of the Bay either.

Tried the usual trinity, but they were out of carnitas.  Instead had carne asada, pastor, and pollo asado.

Carne Asada: overcooked downer meat, not much fun.

Pastor: Greasy, red, greasy.

Pollo Asado: Best of the bunch.  Not extravagant, but tasty.

For $1.75 a pop, this ain't Oakland.  And not a great deal either. 

Maybe this is the kind of taqueria where you should have the burritos instead. 

Seeking more taco trucks?  See my Mexican food list here:
http://www.yelp.com/list_details?list_id=7moDaSk5jQWRZ76X3AbyFA
author: Daniel S.

description: this place is good the tacos are small but tasty morsels of about $2 each and I have gone all the way there just to have them, but their menu is misleading they say they have tripe and brain tacos but they never do so they should change their menu so people don't go across town just for them
author: N A.

description:
Had a pollo asado taco yesterday at the Zin tasting and MAN did it hit the friggin' spot!  It was so good, so juicy and tender those little chicken pieces, that I sucked their juices from my fingers.  I tried to savor the deliciousness, caress my palate, but I couldn't stop NOM-NOM-ING.  

I only had one, though I wanted eight.  It's a good thing this truck isn't in my neighborhood and that I'm usually nowhere near it most of the time because I'd get one of those cool fishing chairs and park my ass for DAYS.
author: Tamar D.

description:
Judge for yourself. I've grown up around Mexican food my entire life, and this place isn't anything special. Just to warn everyone, I ordered the regular chicken, it tasted really strange. I took a closer look and found the chicken was still raw, bloody and uncooked! That went straight in the trash.

I've also gave the carne asada tacos a try. They too, left much to be desired. I really don't understand the reviews, other than yes, "this place is good for cheap and quick tacos". Remember, you will get what you pay for.

This is not a place to go if you're looking for a really good taqueria. It will never take the place of the well known best spots - La Taqueria, Pancho Villa, Super Tac, etc.
author: Roberto K.

description:
Pancho Who?

No, but seriously, why wait 20 minutes to order at Pancho Villa when El Tonayense is so much better?  And when I say better I mean even if you get it To-Go and don't have a chance to eat it for 15 minutes, it's still better than whatever you could've gotten elsewhere.  San Francisco's Mobile Tacqueria Brigade is a wonder of modern culture.

I like to play a little game of "Give me as many Carne Asada tacos as you can fit on the plate."  So what if I've gained 20 lbs. since moving to San Francisco.  There's no correlation, okay?  Shut up.
author: Adam W.

description: Don't be scared to go eat out of a taco truck. This place follows health code and I've eaten there plenty of times - never a problem! You can smell the taco truck blocks away. BEST TACOS IN TOWN hands down! Their tacos are way better than the tacos sold in any typical Mexican restaurants. They're convienient and right outside of Best Buy's parking lot. My boyfriend likes the lengua (tongue) tacos, but I'd rather stick to the carne asada. Spicy please with an orchata on the side.
author: Gina P.

description:
No trip to Best Buy would be complete without grabbing a couple of tacos from the El Tonayense taco truck that seems to be perpetually parked outside. It kind of reminds me of the symbiotic relationship between a shark and a lamprey. Not that I'm drawing comparisons to Best Buy being a bloodthirsty  predator that only wants your money despite their completely inept and uninformed staff while El Tonayense is a parasitic leech that survives solely off the success of Best Buy. Hey, that's not bad. Maybe I AM saying that.

No matter, El Tonayense is a legitimate business on its own serving up tacos, burritos, tortas and Cuban sandwiches. I've had the Cuban sandwich before and they're just alright. Your best bet is to stick with the tacos because they're delicious, simple and dirt cheap. Any time I can feed myself for $5 and not regret it, I'm stoked.
author: Josua P.

description: Wow it is all about the green salsa. And there's something different about how they make their tortillas that is SO good. Service is generally fast and easy. I did have a minor issue once where the woman taking my order got really confused and had to ask me three times what I ordered. That day the food took longer than normal (she was probably new) and the burritos were labeled backwards when we got them, but that aside the food was delicious as always.
author: Jenn J.

description:
I'm from Modesto. Let's just get that right out of the way. Anyone who knows anything about Modesto knows a couple basic things about it...

1) It gets hotter than shit (triple digit heat waves are guaranteed every summer).

2) It's ghetto (consistantly ranks in the top three cities for auto theft in California, often topping out Oakland).

3) There's a STRONG latin influence (being that the city limits are bordered by farm land theres a ton of migrant workers in addition to the already strong latin culture in the city of Mo).


Based off our third key Modesto trait one can assume that I love authentic mexican food (namely street tacos) more than any other food IF (and that's a huge if) they're done right. 

Most of the time I hate tacos from taquerias. Simply put they complicate it to much (no pun intended). The point of an authentic taco is to capture the flavor of the meat, seasoning and a few other elements meant to compliment but not take away from that flavor. There's no need for lettuce, cheese, sour cream and all this other garbage on a taco. It just dilutes the flavor of the good stuff in my opinion.

A properly made street taco will consist of...

-Your choice of grilled meat. Asada, Pollo or Puerco (no chile colorado or any of that shit, save that for traditional style platas)  seasoned and grilled to perfection (this is the key to a great street taco).

-A small amount of onions, cilantro or both

-A squeeze of lime

-SOMETIMES a small dab of guacamole or pico de gallo (be sure to not overdo it as you'll mask the flavor of the meat and, again, the meat is what the taco is all about!)

When these key elements come together just right it's a thing of beauty. 

But as I stated above many places pile on as much as they can, overcharge you for a shitty "super" taco and then end up laughing at your gringo style taco. Did you ever notice how those small tortillas end up getting all overloaded, soggy and falling apart before you can get halfway through a "super" taco? It's because they weren't meant to handle all of that crap!!

With that being said I've found that the most authentic street tacos I've found are from the taco trucks when it comes to eating stateside. They had em all over the place in Modesto. I understand that there's quite a few in Oakland, not so many here in the city. 

So for providing what's pretty much as close as I've tasted to an authentic street taco as you'll get here in the city (the trucks often pan fry the meat as opposed to grilling it, and yes I know I'm a picky bastard when it comes to this) I give El Tonayense a five star review. To anyone who ever finds themselves in Mexico I recommend finding a street-side grill cart and trying authentic street tacos for yourself. Sorry for the serious rambling that I did in this review but as you can probably tell, I loves me a good taco (as sexually inferencing as that sounds).
author: Tommy P.

description:
