Back in the days when people could make a good living working part time in cargo shorts with their dog snuggled around their ankles at a web design firm occupying a former winery in the Mission . . . people like me . . . I stumbled across the El Tonayense truck that was always parked at Harrison and 22nd Street.  My coworkers and I were on a mission (pun intended) to try out every taqueria within walking distance of our office, but for some reason, they were all scared to try the truck.  

One day I said "Fuck it - I'm going to the truck!"  One of my best acts of nonconformity ever.  The food is fantastic.  The BBQ pork is unbelievable.  Best burrito ever.  And they have coke in bottles!  Nowadays, every Mexican place in the City has coke in bottles, but back then, before the bubble burst, it was not yet the case.  

Drinking coke out of a glass bottle reminds me of my childhood and makes me feel all warm and fuzzy inside.  Plus, Mexican coke is made with sugar (no cory syrup!  Yay!)  so it isn't quite as bad for ya as the gringo version.

As an aside, "El Tonayense" means "The dude from Tonaya."  Tonaya is a town in Mexico.  There ya have it.  

In sum:  DON'T BE AFRAID OF THE TACO TRUCK!
author: Joe C.

description:
No trip to Best Buy would be complete without making a stop at the El Tonayense taco truck.  Having just ventured to the El Tonayense taco truck at 16th and Shotwell the day before, we couldn't help ourselves to craving more of their delicious tacos.

We ordered a couple carne asada and carnitas tacos ($1.75 each).  The meat was tasty (carnitas were better than the carne asada) and the corn tortillas were warm and slightly crisp on the edges.  But there was significantly less meat, less onions, less cilantro and less hot sauce than what we had been given the day before.  And the employees of this taco truck were not very friendly either.

There ain't nothing like devouring a couple tasty tacos and having your fingers smelling like onions afterward, as you fiddle with all of the electronics from Best Buy.
author: Diane L.

description:
Sometimes you need a trip to Best Buy (the receiver blew, so did the DVD player, you are the last person in the history of the universe to have TIVO because you think you already watch too much TV and isn't that what HBO-on-demand (the only channel you truly watch except for Comedy Central and PBS) is for, but now you've decided it's finally time because you keep missing South Park and no way is the boyfriend going to tolerate Sundays watching Jane Austen).

When that happens, you might feel -- as I do -- that the shopping trip is necessary but not fun.  I like appliances as much as the next person, but the sheer volume of Best Buy exhausts me in a very IKEA-like way.  Certain things get you through those shopping-is-hell moments, and those things boil down to food.  As a kid, it was the milkshake bribes from my mother in dept stores, or the Big Wheels (ice cream sandwiches) after interminal trips to mall land.  At IKEA, it's the fro yo at the end.  At Best Buy, it's the resident El Tonayense Taco truck.  

Great product, too, worth even a solo trip.  Carnitas, pollo asado, the pollo, they're all good in tacos (which is all I've ever had here).  And go for the spicy, not the mild.  It's just the right balance of kick and flavor.  A nice Sierra Nevada and it would be five stars.  But that's wishful thinking.
author: Laurel B.

description: EL TONAYENSE IS MUY CALIENTE! I saw this truck featured on KQED's fun show, Check Please, which is like a TV version of Yelp and totally wanted to check out the place. The reviewers raved about the place like little kids in a candy store and I knew I would fall in love with this place. For less than 7 bucks, I had gotten everything from chips, to soda, to carnitas tacos, al pastor tacos, carne asada tacos, and more! I would drive 50 miles to SF when I have a craving for this place which sounds crazy but it was that good! In one sitting, the most I had was 4 tacos and chips and a Sunkist. Oh, did I feel bloated but satisfied. It's the salsa I tell you which literally shoots out of your taco when you bite into them. Don't wear a white shirt or anything nice when eating these tacos, they will stain your clothes! I love this location because it's right next to the freeway and parking is a cinch with the Best Buy just right there!
author: Danster L.

description:
A good fix if you're...
...on foot.
...needing your burrito/taco jones satiated immediately.
...at the Harrison Best Buy and starved.
...all of the above.
If you have wheeled transportation and a little patience...
...there are many better choices within 5 minutes.
author: Barry A.

description:
Come with me for a journey down the grizzly end of the meat menu.  I've often viewed the menu of a taco truck with suspicion.  I consider myself a deep end diner in some ways but usually confine my offal excursions to the safe haven of a two Michelin star restaurant.  However one drunken night out in Pomona my friends decided to play a trick on the poor little white boy and bought me some tripitas tacos from a truck outside the bar we had been frequenting.  Wow, wow, wow, wow.  Sadly I was too drunk to remember the name of the truck or i'd be yelping that.  My friends were surprised at my reaction especially when they revealed i'd been eating tripe.  But I thank them for the experience and giving me the balls to venture down the menu.

Sober and in complete control I went to my favourite truck outside Best Buy and was happy to see they really did offer nose to tail eating.  So I made it my mission to try each one.  

I've made a vain attempt at ranking each meat but truth be told with one exception I'd eat them all again.

Tripitas (Tripe)

The pinnacle of tacodom.  Tripitas or tripe is the intestine of a pig or cow (I think these are the beef variety but unsure) which I presume from the consistency is stewed and then fried to give it a lovely soft interior with a crunch that is reminiscent of pork crackling (or ciccarones if you've never had crackling).  The taste is quite neutral with a little porkiness but it is the consistency that makes these five star tacos.  I even once got a freebie from the nice people at ETbecause they were impressed that I was venturing outside of my culinary comfort zone.

Cabeza (Head & Cheek).  

Now I'm a big fan of pigs head, if you go to Marseille you'll find them in every butcher shop window and at El Tonayense the delicious, tender pieces are chopped up so you wouldn't recognise them as their constituent parts.  Imagine if you will a very robust flavoured Carnitas, minus the crunch and you are pretty much there.  I presume they are simmered for a long time to break down the meat and would be my preference now over Al Pastor any day of the week. 

Lengua (Tongue)

By far the most distinctive flavour of the menu.  Tongue has a rich, almost livery taste to it and again it is well cooked and chopped so the meat is tender.  I like the robust flavour and still pick one up from time to time.

Buche (Neck)

Pig's neck?  I have found conflicting information as to whether this is neck or stomach from the pig but tasting them seems to point to neck.  I would say the taste is pretty ordinary and the consistency that of Carne Asada.  That said it is a tasty treat and I would have no trouble eating them but find little to recommend them over some of the other offally good offerings.

Sesos (Brains)

The holy grail of deep end dining?  I really had to build myself up to eating brains as my first experience of this in a restaurant in Dubai was not pleasant.  I have to say my second experience was also unpleasant, the flavour is strong and overpowering, even hot sauce couldn't keep it from taking over every other taste on the tortilla and the consistency was very spongy, almost mushy.  I did however manage to eat the whole thing but I do consider this to be an acquired taste and not one I really want to try and acquire myself.

If you aren't as brave as me (or stupid perhaps) then ET does offer tasty morsels at the easier end of the menu.  I love their Al Pastor, it really tasted like it was barcecued but please I implore you, put your reservations aside and try a Tripitas Taco, you will never look back!
author: Tony S.

description:
Can you believe this was my FIRST time trying a taco at a taco truck???

Seriously, a guy introduced me to it day two in our initial meeting and I recently mustered up the nerve and buckled down to try a taco.  

I was kind of nervous at first when I ordered but after seeing the long line of people waiting to order after me was very reassuring.   And it turned out GREAT! What can I say? ;) 

Now I am craving it every now and then and even notice other El Tonayense trucks when they drive past me in SOMA. 

 Cheap, well-cooked, great service and when you're in as much  of hurry as I am these days - it is simply the perfect re-charge to make me a happy cat.
author: Yelper A.

description:
When my friend first brought up the idea of going to the taco truck, I was all like "No. NO. Oh HELLLLLL no."  And he was all like "i'm just sayin', over a hundred reviews on Yelp, 4.5 stars".  And I was all like "we have the entirety of San Francisco's culinary offerings at our feet this glorious Saturday afternoon, and you want to eat curbside at a taco truck?  Like ANIMALS?" And he was all like "Pfft, whatever, I'm just sayin'".
 
And I was all like, "fine".  But i couldn't hide my antitacotruckitude from my friend - he could tell I was far from jazzed.  But I went anyway, like a lemming, determined to hate it extra so I could unceremoniously rub it in his face that he recommended a crappy place to eat.  
 
My dudes, I was wrong.  Dead wrong.  Best tacos in SF.  Period.  And, it should be noted, I've eaten my fair share of tacos in SF.  

I love food that artfully straddles the line between impossibly cheap and incredibly delicious.  Such does the food at this place.
 
Here's all you need to know:
 
"Dos tacos al pastor con todo y una horchata, por favor y gracias". 

I've now been to this taco truck eight times.  In the past month.  Don't judge me!  Or, at least, *before* you judge me, go try an al pastor taco, curbside.  Go on, I'll wait here.
author: Caroline E.

description:
In a word, impressive. Would you really drive somewhere...to get food from a place on wheels? Well I did. You should too.

I've been here twice - the first time was when stupidly assuming that Best Buy would sell fans we decided to purchase a taco. This was a smart idea. A very delicious al pastor taco! Meat crispy and full of flavor - served the way a taco should be: on a corn tortilla with cilantro and some salsa. I was impressed, it was a good taco. I will be returning I said.

Then there was Check, Please Bay Area - I was definitely surprised to see this place reviewed on there, but not utterly shocked given that one of the three guests will undoubted choose some lesser known establishment (when the other two choose something like La Folie or Postrio). I think the most shocking thing was that all 3 guests liked it. My reaction was "Come on, really?"

That was one of the several impetuses for me returning - not the least of which is just my fairly regular desire for mexican food.

Carne Asada Super Burrito with no rice and beans. Asked for my salsa medium. Again -  I will not do rice and beans in a burrito. They do not belong. But anyway, EUREKA. What a tasty burrito, there were all kinds of flavors in this burrito, if you were to connect sensors to the various parts of my tongue they'd all be lighting up. The meat and salsa here are tremendous. The integration of the various ingredients was well done. Even at lunch time when it was getting busy they were pretty quick to give me my food. This place is clean. Very clean. All the fixtures are shiny. No weird smells emanating from the truck.

Negatives? well $6 is reasonable for a super burrito, a little high but not the worst by any means. The guacamole wasn't very chunky, it was more of an avocado cream from what I could tell and I do like my guacamole, as you know.

Do not feel weird going here and ordering from a place on 4 wheels. Thomas Keller is upset he didn't think of it first. Trust me, I asked him.
author: Ross R.

description:
This would definitely be categorized as a greasy spoon....if only they actually had spoons.

Sporks?  No.  Any utensils at all?  Well, plates...yeah, call this a greasy plate.  You see, you wouldn't normally categorize a Taco Truck as a greasy spoon (err, plate) but the amount of grease that rolled off my plate of Carne Asada tacos was profound, folks....profound.  Mind you, this was after some had already sunk into the two to three plates that the tacos were served on!!  Still, at $1.75 a piece, you really can't go wrong.  So what if as you're walking away you keel over from a myocardial infarction...at least you'll have had some of the cheapest, tastiest tacos in town.  The question is, will it compare to that bright taco truck in the sky?
author: Melanie N.

description:
Carnitas, pastor, carne asada, pollo.  Oh man, my mouth just started to drool just thinking about these tacos.  Just the right amount of spice in the salsa, a little onion and cilantro along for the ride.  Delicious!  Oh and those tasty pickled jalapenos - yes!!!

Perfect little street tacos in a nice, well lit Best Buy parking lot.  Got to love it.
author: Kim M.

description: Now I have only ever been to the one outside of the Mission Cliffs climbing gym, but the El Tonayense truck there has the best tasting tacos I have come across in a while. Super delicious all the time!
author: Vanessa G.

description: I brought a burrito for 6 bucks 0100 in the morning after work.  He was station on California st. near Montgomery st.  I ate the mild burrito, it had no taste shoulda got some spice on it at the truck.  I was hungry as long as it don't taste bad.  He was nice to me and made sure which meat i wanted.
author: John F.

description:
What a beautiful day when I can go buy the latest game for my PS3, then come outside for a few carne asada tacos, washed down with a sugary Pepsi!  Doesn't get much better than that.  

This is the kind of thing that keeps me from moving out to the suburbs.
author: Sheila G.

description:
I finally got around to getting some tacos from the most famous line of taco trucks in SF, so famous they even got reviewed on "Check Please Bay Area". 

The verdict is in: the tacos were very good - no let down, no complaints. But I still like the taqueria in my neighborhood just as much, El Gran Taco Loco on Mission Street @ 29th in Bernal Heights. 

I had 3 tacos: carne asada, al pastor and carnitas. They were all very good with good salsa. I was not let down in the least, I just didn't think they were better than El Gran Taco Loco. If I was hungry and shopping at Best Buy I would be happy to eat food from this truck again (or their other locations), but I am not going out of my way to leave Bernal Heights for a different source of equally great tacos.
author: Yvette K.

description: The cashier needs to learn how to use proper food handling technique. The only gripe I have about this truck is that the cashier adds the veggies and wraps up the burrito and I've never seen them use hand sanitizer. Other than that the food is damn tasty.
author: Jonathon C.

description:
We came here after seeing it featured on KQED's Check Please!

Hubby and I shared 3 beef tongue tacos, a super carne asada burrito, and a super pollo asada torta, chips, and an horchata and a pineapple drink.   We were so happy to eat outside sitting in the back of Hubby's truck.  yum yum...  The burrito was nice and saucy with the guac and sour cream.  The torta was wonderfully tasty... and we had to fight over the 3rd tongue taco.  We might have ordered a little too much food as 30 minutes later we barely make it home before taking a 20 minute food coma nap.   The rest of the day, I was pretty full.  

2 Days later, I go back with brother and good friends.   We all mainly had 2 tacos and shared a super carne asada burrito.  Except this time we tried the tripe taco as well as a tongue taco.  Definitely the spicy salsa is yummier and the tongue is much better than the tripe.

oh btw, I love that pineapple drink.  I think I can drink a whole vat of it.  So tasty.   My brother thought it tasted a little like orange julius.  yum yum...
author: Regi K.

description:
I was fucking starving and about to hit the road/ get on the freeway to go camping.  Parking in San Francisco is abysmal and the food is expensive.  Enter: taco truck right next to massive parking lot.  A winning combination, if I've ever seen one.  Veggie tacos, low prices, plentiful parking, aguas frescas, air conditioning.  Good things alone, sure, but in concert?  Wonderful!
Another tidbit:  if there is a line, it moves very quickly-- these guys are pros!
author: Christy T.

description:
YUM. YUUUM. This burrito so hits the spot. I heart lengua burritos (yes, I like cow tongue). And I super heart super lengua burritos at Tonayense. At six bucks or so I am very happily stuuuuufffeed. 

I saw the episode of Check Please that the "High Tech Product Designer" recommended this taco truck. For those of you who don't know what Check Please is, it's a show where 3 guests come and each recommend a restaurant. The other guests all try each other's restaurants and give reviews. 

Soooo I think the episode featuring Tonayense was the first time a TACO TRUCK was recommended rather than a restaurant. HA! And (me also being in the "high tech" field) I got a kick out of the fact that this computer geek recommended this place. Like a true engineer. Why would we geeks want to socialize with ppl in a (heaven-forbid) *restaurant* when you can just order and shove an amazing burrito down your throat without talking to anyone and without any awkward eye contact with your waitress as your cheeks puff up like chipmunks'. No wonder all my Adobe-work-folk love going to taco trucks. This one's the best one close to work! And lucky for other ppl not in the area, they have like five locations. Go Tonayense!
author: Christine L.

description:
Overseasoned, but an addiction.

The little guy hates it when I tell him I sometimes go to one of the other El Tonayense trucks.  

He could've spit in my burro, but made it extra big.

"Tips are for Sexy People"
author: Peter A.

description:
Dude.... Cali talk... 

All El Tonayense Taco Trucks are not created equal!  This one is better then the others???  How does it happen.  Whoever is running this one you guys need to give him a raise.  I have eaten at all of them and the others are not as good....
author: Christopher F.

description:
$1.75 gets you a completely delicious carne asada taco with a jalapeno spear and a radish slice, served up in a hot, greasy, slightly crispy tortilla. The $1.75 thing is deceptive because you're going to want  about five of these hotties plus some chips and at least one soda cuz at the taco truck, hot sauce means Hot Sauce. 

You're either going to eat these nasty boys a) awkwardly standing somewhere near the taco truck  b) sitting on a curb in between cars in the Best Buy parking lot, which is convenient because then you're going to have to go into Best Buy just to throw away your taco trash and even more convenient if, like me, you're still in the throes of an agonizing reappraisal of how much you want the new Rihanna cd...
author: Zoe B.

description:
I'm a girl that's easy to please and being a California native, there is nothing more satisfying than food from your local taco truck. You know the one, that mysterious truck with shiny silver lining and awning that some how produces the most comforting, delicious eats around. I haven't lived in San Francisco for awhile, so I relied on "Check Please" for the tip on this particular truck. It seemed that they had nothing but good things to say, so I thought, what the hell, I'll give it a spin. 

Mexican cuisine has a special way of turning atypical cuts of meat into pure perfection, so I expected this taco truck to have the full arsenal of proteins. It turned out that they had a great selection, so in true Christina-fashion, I went with tripas and lengua street tacos. Both of the meats could have stood to be simmered a little longer, but luckily Tonayense serves a kick-ass chipotle taco sauce along with the cilantro and onions. The sauce propelled the taco to the next level and made for a uniqueness about this taco truck. Not bad for a mobile eatery, but I'm still remaining optimistic in finding a better truck to satisfy my hunger.
author: Christina N.

description: It is hard to beat the tacos from this truck. The fact the tacos are under $2, makes it a bargain.
author: Bob b.

description: Been eating here pretty regularly for the last couple weeks since I moved here from SD.  Now it would be totally unfair to compare this to the Mex joints in SD, I gotta say, the food here is quite respectable.  Tacos are quite tasty and pretty affordable.  Likewise with the burritos.  Burritos come with beans, rice, salsa and whatever meat you choose.  I've taken a liking to the carnitas here.  I've tried the lengua and it's a bit on the mushy side for me.  Nothing much stands out with the chicken or carne asada but I'll give those another chance.  They also serve mexicoke here.  Awesome.
author: Dan P.

description: No.  No!  Very forgettable Mx food.  Let's get it right guys.  The best thing we had was the Jarritos.  No water?  You couldve killed it that day if you'da stocked up on water!!! And don't charge six something for a small burrito that doesn't deliver on flavor or contents.  I'm sorry for being honest, but with a name like yours, it should be more than decent.  I might have gone on a bad day.  I'm picky about my Mx food.  I get to be, though...
author: Joshua K.

description:
Who knew eating from a taco truck would be sooooo good. 

They have the most interesting selection of meats tho i'll have to be honest like brain and internal organs, tripe, ear, heart, liver, beef tongue, etc.  

I met up my sister and her friends for a nice lunch here.  And omg, its cheap too.  And so each of us had about two tacos and half a burrito.  I'd definitely suggest going witht he super, and by super, its not size, but the additional guac and sour cream, which to me is a MUST in burritos.  

The pineapple drink is also amazing.  It tastes like orange julius kind of, but definitely if you're around the area, find one of these taco trucks and give it a try.
author: Vincent K.

description: A good friend of mine had this truck catering his baby shower and it was the first time I had tried it. I've always seen it parked outside of Best Buy on Harrison, but never had time to stop and order some food. Although the burritos were kind of small, I had two, which was enough to fill me up. Very flavorful burritos and we definitely stop by this truck again if time ever allows it.
author: Jeff L.

description:
I want to give 6 stars. There should be some secret code that will award six stars to those who are worthy! This place was INCREDIBLE! I took my entire office (yep, all 4!) One who was terrified to eat from a truck and three who couldn't wait for the adventure! 

Fine grain rice, not too much cheese, sliced tomatoes, guacamole and what sealed the deal for the best burrito ever.... the SAUCE! A special mild (or hot) sauce with the perfect bite and flavor. I just can't get enough! 

Also to be had were the carnitas and carne asada, which both were reviewed as delicious. Just to prove my point the next day my coworkers were on the hunt for me because they wanted to "go to the taco truck" again. I love it! Oh, and the girl who was scared to eat from a truck said this was the "best lunch idea she has ever heard of". On that note, I am giving myself five stars for once again rocking my coworkers lunch world! El Tonayense you win best burrito in SF. Hands down my friend!
author: Jen B.

description:
Beyond tasty tacos!  I heard about "a taco truck off the freeway" being featured on the Food Network so asked friends about it and sure enough, one suggested that it might be Tonayense.  I went not knowing if this was "the" taco truck off the freeway, saw the plaques and awards that it had won, and was amazed at the taste sensation, mmmmmm!!

To be fair, I only eat chicken, so can only comment on those as I've eaten both the "pollo" and "pollo asado", two different methods of cooking.  The pollo is slow cooked in a red sauce and is super moist, and seasoned beautifully.  The pollo asado is just that, grilled meat, very well flavored, cooked, and good quality white meat chicken.  I've taken friends here and they have liked the carne asada and another of the beef styles, they swear by them, so it sounds like it's all good.

After many visits of just the tacos, because why fix it if it isn't broken, I decided to venture out with a burrito.  Good tortilla, as many others fail in this respect, but overall I would give it an ok, not to be ordered again, I'll stick with the tacos and am going to try the torta one of these days.  **update**  A good friend of mine who is all about Mexican food in SF, ventured into the burrito ordering and loved his carne asada burrito.  We are both trying to get the guts to order the quesadilla, the tacos are too good to leave!

The horchata is really good too, one of the best in the Bay.  

I love El Tonayense truck, I had friends from out of town visit so went into the Mission for the actual store location since getting to the taco truck would have been a long adventure in and of itself, and with two small kids visiting, this wasn't going to happen.  So I would rate the actual Tonayense restaurant really good, but the truck on Harrison and 13th beyond exceptional, like fantastic!!
author: Miss C.

description:
This taco truck has the cleanest floor I have seen in a restaurant, let alone a roach coach. It sparkles. I want my bathroom floor to sparkle like that. 

Boyfriend was dubious when I insisted on eating at the taco truck after a trip to Best Buy, but like I've established in the first paragraph, he was quickly won over by the cleanliness and prominently placed "A" health ratings.

All the burritos I've had are bursting with your choice of ingredients, and mine was loaded with sour cream and hot sauce as well. Heavenly! The food was is so friggin delicious we finished our entire veggie and pollo burritos in about 10 minutes.  We were delighted to find Horchata and Mexican Coke ready for us as well! 

Extra points to the nice man serving us for not blinking when he mispronounced pollo. I guess we didn't all take Spanish in high school. Speaking of non Spanish speakers, be sure to note the English translations... and be warned, sesos means brains!
author: Kelly C.

description:
Hot damn this place is good.

Went here the first time because we were at Office Depot.  They messed up my burrito order, but it was so good the messed up way that we drove down here for our second visit to order the screw-up...and we didn't even need to go to Best Buy.

We guessed (correctly) that the messed up burrito was a carne asada super burrito with no beans.  Trust me, it's delicious.  Their sour cream/guacamole is incredible...super tasty with a garlic twang.  And their chicken tacos are good and wet too.
author: Pink ..

description: I had the truck for a private party and it was the best way to go!  They were super easy to talk to on the phone, we made all the arrangements via email and they showed up exactly on time.  The price was right, my guests loved the food and no one went hungry.  The servers were friendly and quick.  I highly recommend this for any party.
author: Patricia M.

description:
Sometimes multitasking is too productive

12:03 pm - heading to Best Buy to pick up a USB cord for my camera.

12:07 pm - diet coke in one hand, carnitas taco in the other entering Best Buy.

12:14 pm - back in my car with my new purchase and lunch eaten.  

12:20pm - Back in the office garage.  It felt too good to be true to hit up an electronics store and get lunch in 17 minutes.  That's when I realized that I forgot to pick up the memory card.

12:26pm - heading to Best Buy to pick up a memory card for my camera.

12:32 pm - grilled chicken taco in hand, entering Best Buy.

12:40 pm - back in my car with my new purchase and lunch eaten again.   

I don't like Best Buy, but I think I'll have to make more trips there because the taco truck is great.  

For lunch on Friday, I'm going to bring a co-worker and have a couple camping chairs stashed in my trunk so we can relax in the parking lot and eat.

Maybe Ed M can come and we can make a contest out of it.
author: amy l.

description:
So I'm a little like Andrew Zimmern when it comes to food.  When I saw Lengua on the menu, I proudly proclaimed to the truck guys I wanted Lengua Burrito, hoping to incite gasps of "Vato, está usted loco?!"

Lengua = beef tongue.  Don't knock it til you try it.  It's tender, succulent meat.  

My coworkers who watched me order were the ones gasping, practically puking on my behalf.  I think it's a texture thing.  If you grow up in America eating hamburgers and hotdogs, beef tongue definitely is different.  Your loss, my gain.
author: Jason Y.

description:
This is a review of the steak burrito - i have heard the pork is better.

I tried them b/c i was too lazy to go to el farolito in the mission, and i was really craving a burrito. i'm not much a pork eater and they were out anyway so i decided to go with the steak. 
I got a super burrito b/c i like everything in it. but even with a super burrito there was a fold in my tortilla - u are doing something seriously wrong when your not using up all the space in a tortilla for a SUPER burrito. 
ok so..
1. burrito was small ( which i can get over b/c my eyes are usually hungrier then my belly anyway)
2. either due to the meat not being hot enough or the sour cream just being ICE COLD. my burrito was cold -not warm.. cold.
3. there was barely anything in my burrito but meat - now NORMALLY i wouldn't complain about this but thats what brings me to number4...
4. quality of the steak was pretty low grade - fatty and  chewy and not tasty. so it would have been nice to have some rice and cheese and pico and guac etc.. to take my mind of the cartilage i was chewing.
author: Shadi N.

description:
Have you ever bitten into a piece of steak and thought to yourself, "Man, the texture of this steak is great, but I wish it were a shitload saltier. In fact, I wish it had the exact taste of salt and nothing but salt"? If so, the El Tonayense Taco Truck on Harrison is for you. 

Salty, salty carne asada was strike one against El Tonayense, and the undercooked beans did little to redeem my burrito. On the bright side, these guys do serve some damn fine chips and salsa for only a dollar.
author: Karin H.

description:
i got an Al Pastor and Carne Asada taco. quite yummie and fast. perfect while running errands.

i just saw the review from today (10/23/2007) saying $2.25 per taco . . . did prices just go up? i ate here on Friday (10/19) and it was $1.75 per taco.
author: Andrew C.

description: Impressive selection of meats.  Makes the task of having to go to Best Buy to get a new vacuum much more palpable.  I had the carne asada torta and it had a nice tangy spiciness to it; not sure if it was part of the meat marinade or torta sauce.  Good amount and quality of steak.  Filled me up nicely.  $5 even with tax included.  If you need cash, try the ATM in Rainbow Grocery nearby.  They seem to have a lot of licenses showing to prove their legitness.  Since it's a truck, there isn't a place to really sit and eat other than your car, which is a downside, and no salsa bar like their Mission establishment so I feel 5 stars is just slightly out of reach for this truck.
author: Marc S.

description:
I've passed by this Taco truck a gazillion times on my bike commute from the Lower Haight to the Caltrain. The other nite I was looking for El Chanchilla before heading over to Slim's for a concert and for the life of me couldn't find it. So I said screw it, letz just ride towards Slims. 

And then and the taco oasis appeared before me...the taco truck that i'd neglected for over a year came to my rescue. I ordered to tacos de pollo asado and 1 taco de lengua. I have to say, these tacos were, fresh, juicy and delicious! Oh and basic just like they should be. Tortilla, meat, hot sauce, diced cilantro and onion...no frills! I should point out that the lengua was not gamy and extremely tender; two key traits of good lengua! I washed it down with a Cidral(sparkling apple juice) and was a happy camper!

I will be back for more tacos!
author: isaias J.

description:
What is going on with Tonayense? I went here last week and the burrito was awful! It was a shadow of what I had first tried here. 

There were only two huge chunks of dried out carnitas and hardly any hot sauce (I asked for it extra hot). 

I fee like someone who has seen a former middle school crush who is now  fat, balding, living at home with his mom and is still wearing his starter jacket. So disappointed the dream is gone.
author: Monica L.

description:
Am I in the twilight zone?  Or does the Taco Truck just hate me? 

I gave them 3 chances.  Every time there was something ick in my taco.  No bugs -- thank the food gods! -- but gobs of fat, big chucks of gristle.  

I get street tacos.  Maybe the burritos are good.  Or maybe it's just that there's such a quantity for such a reasonable price some people cut them slack.  I just can't.
author: nomi c.

description:
A reliable staple of my new neighborhood, the tacos here are fresh and tasty... plus they have Mexican coke (the stuff made with azúcar instead of corn syrup).  

¡Overall, muy bueno y barato!
author: Matthew P.

description:
SO. GOOD.

this place is even cleaner than most  taquerias

and that aint no joke....
author: Anthony N.

description:
There's something very satisfying about having a spicy al pastor taco with a cold Mexican Coke from the bottle. It's even better because they're only $1.75 each and come straight off the griddle in just a couple minutes.

You can find me seated on the curb in front of Best Buy licking my fingers with a big smile on my face.
author: Nina L.

description:
A heroin addict is to rubber tie-offs and hypodermic needles filled with fresh heroin as Gabe is to the Tonayense Taco Truck.


The best tacos in the city are in a truck?! That shiz is only like $1.35?! The truck was awarded a cleanliness commendation from the department of health?! It's next to Best Buy with parking spots usually open right in front of the truck?! You can wander around afterwards, procuring electronics while you digest?!

Shut your face. You are a liar.
author: Gabe M.

description:
The proximity to Best Buy combines two things I love - electronics and burritos.  So already this taco truck gains my praise.

I ordered a super burrito, al pastor, and I was pleased.  The meat was not as tender as some of the better taquerias, but the seasoning was good.  The sauce they add to make the burrito spicy actually makes the burrito spicy, unlike a lot of taquerias / taco trucks that I've been to.  The ingredients weren't mixed up quite as well as I would have hoped, but this was a tasty burrito nonetheless.  I would like to go to the actual taqueria sometime and see how it compares.

The bottle of Mexican Coke I got wasn't cold (it wasn't warm, but it needed to be on ice or in a real fridge) which was sorely disappointing.

If you're in the area, it's worth stopping by.  Otherwise, hit up a real taqueria in the Mission.
author: Joseph N.

description:
the tacos here are OK in my experience, somewhat inconsistent, the meat sometimes looks (and chews) like jerky when it comes on a taco... 

but the 4 stars is for one menu item: 

SUPER POLLO 'QUESADILLA'   

that's whats up. for real. I don't know what they put in the sauce, if its a novel form of orally active crack, heroin, or what.. but its super friggin tasty.

not the cleanest (as in messy, not dirty), or most aesthetically oriented culinary experience, but it is goddamn delicious. I dont know how its a quesadilla, either, its more like a burrito with no rice... the sauce makes it kinda wet and drippy, but for some reason i still love it.

...I have to add that since i drafted this review, we hired this truck for a work event and they killed it!  People walking by were so pissed that it wasn't open to the public. Everything they did that night was above par, it was great, including the tacos.
author: D L.

description:
Oh my god this place is so good!  I'm relatively new to SF but out of the 10 or so burrito places I've been this is hands down the best.  The roll the burrito nice and tight.  It has the perfect balance of fillings, not too soupy not to dry. 

Everything is good here but the Al Pastor burrito is my favorite.  The prices are good and the service is fast.  I'd give them five stars but there is no place to sit which is mildly annoying.   Somebody should design a food truck with a fold out bench.
author: Garrett D.

description:
Wow this is some good S**T!!  
I've heard so many great things about this taco truck I'm surprised there aren't any reviews on this one at Best Buy.  The tacos are great and cheap, the guys were friendly and most importantly the truck was clean.  I think I even saw a letter posted from the Health Dept. commending them on their high standards.  There's only one negative and that's the runny guac they use.
author: Norm L.

description: Love their burrito. Clean place and their sauces are very tasty. I have been eating tonayense burritos for quite a while, I am a regular. The pork burrito is my favorite and my husband love their lengua tacos.
author: Erika A.

description:
Tastiest tacos I've ever had.  While everyone raves about the al pastor taco/burrito (and I do agree on its deliciousness), my personal favorite is the lengua (tongue) taco.  It may not be palatable to some, but it is juicy and delicious - my staple everytime I stop by.  Also, I am usually not a fan of burritos, but I will gladly eat a burrito, any burrito from El Tonayense.  

Parked on the right side of the Best Buy parking lot, they are there 7 days and week and practically have their own address!  It's even listed on google maps. 

Bottom line: come here for some of the best mexican taco truck food you will ever experience.
author: Nancy J.

description:
Reasons to go: You are hungry. You don't want a large meal nor do you want to settle down at a table for a meal. You are craving tacos.

I have only had the tacos, which hit the spot for a quick snack. Maybe you're on the way to Rainbow or downtown but craving zesty lime squeezed over your tacos and those delicious pickled jalapenos. Something to fill that empty void. Well, these tacos are no nonsense, perhaps not amazingly special, but I enjoy them. Do try the hot sauce if you like spicy.
author: Faye P.

description:
I'm an LA girl. I love me some LA taco trucks. That being said, I'm so starved for good Mexican food in this taco truck forsaken town, I'm not quite sure if I loved this place because I really liked the food, or if I've just eaten so much crappy SF Mexican food that my taste buds are all shot to hell.

Anyhoo, qualifiers aside, I heart me some tacos and some quesadillas from El Tonayense. This is not fancy stuff, but it's not supposed to be.Their meat is legit ,as is their salsa.  Oh and get the hot stuff or forget about it. And praise big baby Jesus they have radishes.!!!

ONE WHOLE STAR because they carry Sidral ( messican apple soda), which made me so happy I almost cried.
author: stephanie c.

description:
Long live the taco truck! 

Absolutely a great and inexpensive meal for any occasion. Cheap and tasty. 

I'm all about the carnitas and the pastor is awesome. Don't let the truck make you nervous- it's a kitchen on wheels. Being from "The Town" (Oakland, people) myself, I don't let it phase me. Some of the best "fast-food" is from trucks and the friendly, hard working-no nonsense people that toil in high heat and small spaces for your taco pleasure. 

A bonus of this particular truck is that the guys who work inside are polite, quick, and always have a smile to offer with their thanks.
author: Jessica D.

description: These guys were fantastic. We hired them to cater a company activity, and everyone was raving about the food. Vinicio always answered my emails promptly and was very nice. The food was hot and so delicious! They also have gluten free and vegetarian options. And great price-wise considering what other food trucks cost these days. I'll definitely be using them again!
author: Molly P.

description: The place I will always stop for a snake. I love the pork taco here, chicken is good as well. Burrito is terrible, that's why I give 4 stars only.
author: Carol X.

description: If there was the option to give El Tonayense 10 stars I would!  They catered our wedding and for the price of $7 a person provided what many people said was the BEST Mexican food they had ever had.  There was a long line to get food because everyone wanted to eat at the same time but that wasn't their fault.  Once orders were placed, they were very fast!  The cooks were very friendly, nice and easy-going!  I highly recommend them!
author: Michelle K.

description:
Yum. And at an excellent price.
$5 for a regular torta, $5.50 for a super. $5.50 for a regular burrito, $6 for a super. Cheap and good.. woot!
author: ToAsTy T.

description:
I like taco truck taco's although my fav spot is in Oakland I live in tha city so 
 this is where I go theTaco's are good if you want a quick Taco fix
author: Kim R.

description:
I hate Best Buy, but I love the taco truck next to it.

I work nearby and have been frequenting El Tonayense for at least a year or two. Having worked all around the Bay Area, I've been fortunate to have had a truck around within reasonable distance at almost every job. El Tonayense is definitely my fave of them all.

Although this truck offers all kinds of meats...er, cuts from pig and beef and chicken, I get the same thing just about 100% of the time: Carnitas Burrito with everything plus hot sauce.

On a good day the burrito will be just about perfect. Meat that's crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. Dripping insides of rice, beans, salsa, sour cream, and hot sauce. Their burritos can be messy so beware and get napkins.

On a bad day, you'll get a piece of meat that comes with a sizeable piece of FAT. What can I say. It's a truck.

With so many choices for burritos in the city, it means something when there's one you go back to over and over. I give four stars since I'm usually pretty happy with my burrito more often than not. I take one off for having raised their prices ($6) to what a lot of restaurants charge. I know it's the city and all so I don't expect the $1 tacos and $3.50 burritos like in Richmond or South SF, but still, IT'S A TRUCK!!!
author: Mike C.

description: =P I'm drooooooling. After I finish my organic rainbow shopping I ALWAYS get the unhealthy, very unorganic tacos here....I can't help it. They are so yummy...
author: Annika K.

description: El Tonayense screwed over an elementary public school at the school fundraiser October 27th.  El Tonayense blackmailed the school just as people at the carnival were ready for lunch. Since they were the only food truck at the event, they simply refused to keep serving food unless their demands were met.  When the school gave in to their demands, instead of continuing to serve their tasty food, they served sub par quality burritos and tacos with no salsa, no grilled chicken.   Their burritos were mostly just a tortilla wrapped in itself.   This was the second year the food truck came to the fundraiser.  No one expected they would pull a stunt like that.
author: A K.

description:
These tacos are amazing for what they are.  Hello--this is a taco truck!  Not exactly a destination spot.  But if you're about to head into Best Buy to look at big screen tvs and you're hungry and you know your boyfriend is going to want to look at *every* tv that he's not actually in the market for, then grab a taco!  The carne asada is pretty good, and the carnitas are excellent.  The al pastor has a strange, indescribable smell (musk?), that I don't care for, but they are more than edible and the meat doesn't seem sketchy. The seasonings just weren't for me.  

I, too, was very skeptical about eating tacos from the truck that is permanently parked outside of Best Buy, when there are so many taquerias in the proximity, but I swear they have some of the best tacos in the area.
author: Cristina C.

description: I hired El Tonayense to cater my wedding and they were amazing.  The food was DELICIOUS, beyond delicious, and they were so easy to work with.  Vinicio always promptly replied to my emails and questions, and he was so willing to work with all my little requests, from using nice plates that I rented instead of paper plates to having chips, guacamole and salsa ready for everyone when the truck arrived.  Everyone loved the food, and loved the fact that we didn't have boring, bland catered food.  I would absolutely hire El Tonayense to cater any event again!  Delicious food and amazing prices!
author: Katherine B.

description:
Overrated to the 10th power.

I don't get why people are in love with this truck.  I guess they've never had great Mexican food.  Either that, or there really like Grumman commercial vehicles.    

OK seriously, it's not that bad.... BUT IT"S NOT THAT GOOD EITHER!

They get 3 stars because they are within walking distance from me and they're next to Best Buy.
author: Larry A.

description: the green salsa is my favorite thing ever (at the moment).  the little tacos are so flavorful it's not like you even *need* the salsa, same for the veggie burrito.  but.  you'll *want* the salsa.  a lot of it, it's insane.  can i buy it in large quantities???  i'm obsessed.
author: Emily T.

description: For coming out of a parked truck outside of Best Buy, the tacos are pretty good. And if you want tongue or intestines, this truck is the place to be. It's reasonably priced, good quality and quick.
author: Julia S.

description: Service is unfriendly, but the carnitas tacos are SO GOOD.  I asked for guacamole, sour cream, and mild sauce (which is green tomatillo) on mine.  The carnitas was tender and flavorful.  No ligaments or chunks of fat.  The tacos went super well will a nice, cold horchata.  I had a carnitas burrito once, and I was not so thrilled.  They need to do something about their guacamole cuz it tastes like watered down cilantro.  Worst guac I've ever had.
author: Kandi K.

description: Their super quesadilla w/chicken ($6.50) is HELLA good! Get your ass over there and try it.  Nuff said. ;)
author: B B.

description:
The food here is decent but watch your money when you pay!!

I used to be a regular at this taco truck and I have never had any issues until today. I selected one of their Al Pastor Super Burritos with no beans ($6.50). I handed the 2 guys a $20 (I am very very certain of this!) but I only got $3.50 back. Fine, people sometimes makes mistakes. I pointed out the mistake and they said "No, no". Then they showed me the money they had in their cash register and conveniently, there were no $20 bills at all there. What pissed me off the most is that they had a big smirk all over their faces!

As a bonus I also got beans in my Burrito.
author: Andy K.

description: My favorite truck period! I like everything they make and everyone I've recommended to it, loves it as well. I couldn't make it any better, and on top of it all, Mexican Coca-Cola. yummmmm!
author: Meg P.

description: I eat tacos or burritos probably 3 days a week, and while I have my favorites, I try new places all the time. I say without hesitation that the El Pastor tacos at the El Tonayense trucks are the best tacos in the City. The price is amazing ($1.75), they are spicy, delicious, and hearty for their size. Anywhere else I order pork tacos of any kind, I just wish I was eating at the El Tonayense truck instead.
author: Gregory P.

description: Tastiest tacos I've ever tasted.  Where else have you seen a Michelin recommendation on a taco truck?
author: John K.

description: One word - superquesadilla (or is that two words?)  Recommend the al pastor - actually drive across town at lunch for this. The little tacos are very good, too, but nothing compares to this quesadilla.
author: Robert M.

description: Best taco truck in SF! Simple, straightforward, authentic no nonsense tacos from what looks to be a clean operation. All the taco meats are good, but I like the marinated pork the best!
author: Nancy F.

description:
ONE OF THE FEW THINGS THAT IS TRULY RIGHT IN THIS WORLD.

dirt-cheap-absolutely-delicious-more-mexican-less-pseudo-califas-"hot sauce means HOT sauce"-our-food-kicks-most-brick-and-mortar-mexican-restaurants GRUB.

drool.  yum.

wash it down with a jarritos soda or an "hecho en mexico" coke in a tall glass bottle (sweetened with *gasp* SUGAR instead of HFCS -- the last real coke on earth).

swoon.  blush.  tumescence.

er... yeah, me likey.  don't turn your nose up at the idea of eating from a restaurant on wheels.
author: Mark B.

description:
I love Mexican food, especially burritos. But recently I've had a change of heart when it comes to tacos.

Tacos are great, but they are meant to be cheap street food.

Unfortunately, I don't find that to be the case with Tonayense's product.  

Their hard to eat, and at $2.50 a piece, why not just get a burrito?

Someone educate me.
author: Jason R.

description:
Fellow yelper/sister raved about her veggie burrito, and I had been craving one ever since. I had high hopes approaching the truck.

Meh.

Now, don't get me wrong, it tasted fine. Edible. Didn't ruin dinner. But there was so much missing. White tortillas only. Veggies were lettuce and tomato only. And the kicker - I was charged the same price as a regular meat burrito even though I didn't want meat, and there was no extra of anything to make up for it.

I was hoping for something special. This was not special.
author: Jason B.

description:
Taco trucks like this hardly fall from the sky.

Super carne asada burrito for $5!!!  This is the best $5 I've spent on a burrito in a long time.  I still need to go to the mission for that legendary burrito.  This place is the better I've tried so far in SF.

I just don't understand why they always ask me "do you have change?" when I give them a $20, because I don't have change that's why I'm giving you a $20!!!
author: Tim L.

description:
Pretty effin good.  Tacos are my new favorite quick food.  Just perfect little containers of meaty goodness.  But it only works if the meat in question posesses said "goodness". 

I've only had the carnitas and the carne asada here, though I really want to try some of the more exotic parts of the cow, like the head and stuff.  I find the meat succulent and flavorful for the most part, but they have off days.  Whatev.  I'll forgive it. 

I've never had a burrito or anything from here, but they used to make cubano sandwiches that were pretty good.  Got me through a few hangovers.  I'm not sure if they still make them though, since they took them off of the sign.

I'm just stoked any time I can get lunch for less than $5, and it doesn't involve pizza.
author: Coco D.

description:
I have a certain affinity for taco trucks and thought I would give this place a try after a stop at Best Buy.

Absolutely great tacos, and cheap.  Anytime I'm in the general vicinity and am looking for some lunch, I find myself heading here.  Highly recommended.
author: Cully W.

description:
This is the best mexican food ever!! And it comes fresh out of a burrito truck. $5 will get you fresh super burrito. The burritos are so fresh that the vegetables in them are still crisp. 
PS: Ask them what is a Mexicana...
author: Dao C.

description:
I was hesitant giving this place a one star review because in the past, I've had pretty good burritos at the truck on 14th and Harrison, HOWEVER, because I had the absolute worst burrito I've EVER had in my life today-- I mean, worse than frozen liquor store burritos-- I have to stick with one star. So what was wrong? EVERYTHING. I always order a super veggie burrito wherever I go... to start with, for $6, it was pretty small. The tortilla was dried out.. maybe it was stale? The rice was under cooked, the beans were undercooked and had zero seasoning of any kind. Ever heard of SALT, guys? There was maybe a teaspoon of cheese about 1/3 of the way in, a barely noticeable smidge of sour cream, no guac or avocado in sight, a few pathetic pink bits of tomato and the salsa? They asked me if I wanted it spicy... I said yes. I don't know what mild salsa is to them, but if the spicy tastes like baby food, I wouldn't know what to expect with mild. I've never had a burrito so bland. Typically, when I gat a subpar burrito, it's still edible. With this one, it was just so so SO bad that I just didn't see the point of wasting the calories on it. I've NEVER taken a burrito back because of quality issues, but I did with this one... I got my money back. If my husband's burrito hadn't been totally lackluster as well, I might have let them make me another, but his was pretty much the same, except he got meat on his and the seasoning on the meat made it palatable... but he should have asked for the difference back for not getting the "super" ingredient upgrade. And on top of it all, we both had a stomach ache an hour later. 

I've been eating burritos about town for years and yes, SF has great burritos.... it's just a matter of finding who's making 'em good right now. If there's anything that's consistent about SF burritos, it's their inconsistency and the propensity for the size and quality of a burrito to plummet every time the truck or restaurant raises prices.  All that said, maybe I'll try these guys again sometime in the distant future. Chances are, I'll get a good one... or another bomb. In any case, I'll come by here to update my experience.
author: Zoe K.

description: Ok... why are people giving this place 5 stars! Are you serious!  I mean this is your average taco trcuk! My buritto was filled with very little pork (greasy pork),  not sure what all the hype is all about!
author: Angelina A.

description:
this place is so consistent.

pretty sure i was the first person there today. tried to get carnita tacos before 10am and the carnitas weren't ready.  got two al pastor tacos.

awesome breakfast of champions
author: Skye W.

description: The tacos here are amazing! I like to get the spicy tacos. Their spicy sauce is really good. I don't know how they make it but it is the perfect combination of flavor and spice. I have tried a burrito here too, and it was okay but now I always get the tacos. The tacos are the best!
author: k j.

description:
If Taqueria Cazadores is closed (alas, Sundays), I'll go here if I'm craving Mexican food. Sadly, their tacos are not as tasty as the crispy shells that I crave from SoCal. I'm just not a big fan of the small, steamed corn tortillas as the larger ones that are fried. 

Oddly, their quesadilla sometimes has almost no cheese. If you order it without meat, they put the expected amount. Sadly, there is no discount for going sin carne.
author: Brian J.

description:
Hells yeah, I love these tacos! Carnitas, beef cheeks, random meat bits, all delish with that slow burn salsa that is sooo good. I'm going there tonight! 

Don't like the creepy guys that come over from the parking lot and try to hit on girls while waiting for tacos though. But the tacos are too good to throw at them. Maybe I'l just borrow my friends big dog. The big barky bitey one, lot monkeys! Taco trucks do not equal pickup joints, there just isn't enough alcohol.
author: Krismet C.

description:
TACOOOOO TOWWWWWWWN!

You know the Saturday Night Live that makes fun of places that sell  "tacos" that are so ridiculously removed from the real thing? El Tonayense is the exact opposite of that skit: These are real deal, no frills, no bullshit tacos, made with virtually part of the cow or pig that you can imagine. And yes, they are damn good!

Taco trucks are occasionally referred to as "roach coaches" because it's probably pretty difficult to enforce health codes and licensing due to their mobility, but that has never stopped me from feasting at them...and it shouldn't stop you from eating El Tonayense's food, because it appears to be incredibly clean.
author: Derek R.

description:
I once ordered a quesadilla here in one of my post mission cliffs kick my ass work out stupors and the cheese wasn't melted. but to understand my disappointment I should explain my kick my ass mission cliffs routine. 15 minutes of warm up bouldering, 2 hours of rock climbing then
 I cool down on the machines for another half an hour before hitting the sauna. I left feeling thoroughly amazing and decided to blow all of it for one quesadilla. I wouldn't have finished but I was fucking hungry and my house was an hour away. Unmelted cheese in a quesadilla is a sin!
author: Nadia P.

description:
I can't believe this sh*t came out of the back of a truck, it was sooo yummy.

Serious burritos and other tacqueria fair.  Also, high on entertainment value watching people pack flat screen into their cars and get in accidents at the intersection.

Serious, entertainment with your taco.
author: Ken p.

description: Love the secret sauce El Tonayense fill their quesadillas, burritos, and tacos with.  A must stop if you're in North Mission/SOMA/Potrero Hill vacinity and if you need to shop at BestBuy, it's a no brainer to plan the visit around a El Tonayense visit.  "THE SF TACO TRUCK" bar-none.
author: Gino R.

description:
I have been eating burritos in the Mission for  years

Truck was Parked in front of Best Buy at 1717 Harrison St
http://maps.google.com/maps?q=1717+Harrison+St+San+Francisco,+CA

(street view  shows picture of Truck)
(they usually have one there until 9 pm)
they have a HUGE Tip Jar

the meat was stale, from a waming tray, 
not cooked to order, with a lot of gristle,
the salsa tasted like it was from a can
the salsa could have been much worse

Taqueria Cancun 2288 Mission Street
has salsa that tastes like sewage

the best goddamn ORGASMIC salsa is at El Castillito
http://www.yelp.com/biz/el-castillito-san-francisco

$5.50 for a corporate tasting burrito ?
you won't fool me twice
oh yeah I've never had gristle in a corporate burrito

Next Time I'll pick up a snack at Rainbow Grocery
or go to 16 & Mission
author: Richard D.

description: Hit 3 taco trucks since moving here.  LOVE this one.  I get 2-3 veggie tacos with hot sauce every time.  And every time they are amazingly good.
author: Jessica M.

description:
Yep , El Tonayense taco truck is the best.
It's in front of Best Buy on Harrison.
Any place that has limes is always a good sign.
 5 stars from 
-Simon the cat.
author: Simon The Cat -.

description:
Ok, I've been back a few more times, and I've been underwhelmed on the last 2-3 visits.  The pastor has been sort of superficially spiced - not achieving the deep, layered flavors of porky, spicy goodness as in further memory.  I've downgraded them a star for that, and for the asshole in the truck who consistently speaks to me in a condescending manner as I practice my Espan~ol when ordering.  I know my grammar isn't the best, but shit I have a degree in it for Christ sake!

PREVIOUS REVIEW:

The Al Pastor alone merits a 5 star rating, simply because it's the best I've found - anywhere.  Whether in taco, burrito or torta form, you can't go wrong.  There is a real depth of flavor to the spices used, like many dried, roasted chilies were blended to create the sauce.  It has sort of a chorizo spice edge to it.  On one occasion, it seemed a little over the top, like cardamom was in the mix, and it tasted like an Indian or Pakistani curry.  On every other visit the Pastor makes my eyes roll back into my head, like some sort of Al Pasteroin or something.  Crazy good.

The other meats merit a 4 star rating for now, but more research must be conducted.  I just can't stay away from the Pastor!
author: Pedro, aka Burgundy M.

description: Simple, rich, spicy, and meaty. I like my burritos how I like my men. This truck delivers on all accounts. Slurp!
author: Delilah P.

description:
I don't get this place's popularity. Why is a burrito more expensive and smaller from a taco truck than from a taqueria that has to pay rent? It shouldn't be. It's also not that great considering all the other great taquerias.

Expensive, small, mediocre, and in this town you don't have to settle for that.
author: jeremy m.

description:
The best tacos come from taco trucks, and the best taco truck is El Tonayense. My personal favorite are the carnitas, but I also like the Carne Asada and Al Pastor quite a bit. I'm not adventurous enough to try some of the other meats but maybe one day.

I think the money is in the salsa. It's a simple spicy and picante sauce, but it's oh so grubbin'. All you need is a lemon wedge a little cilantro and you're good to go. Three green backs gets you two tacos and that's just right for a taste, or as a compliment to something else. Three to four is probably optimal to really  fill up on.
author: riz n.

description:
I don't much "get" burritos (booing, rotten fruit projectiles).  I realize in San Francisco this is blasphemy.  Too bad. However, for Significant Other they are an essential building block of life. Therfore, I have tried many. MANY.

The burritos at El Tonayense are the only ones I could possibly crave. I think its because they put chipotle salsa on them, so it tastes a little like BBQ, the true object of my affection.  So these burritos are essentially my beer-goggles BBQ.  She's not perfect but she'll do in a pinch.

Plus its food from a truck.  I love that.  It's like a reverse drive-thru.

Alas, about a year ago, this truck supplanted Panchanguera from the same spot.  They had cuban pork sandwiches that were fabulous but the burritos weren't as good.  El Tonayense, please consider cuban pork sandwiches!
author: Monkeyfaced E.

description:
I've been to this place three times in the past month.  That is more frequent than any other place I eat except my work cafeteria.  That's how much I like the food here!  Favorites:
1. Carne asada tacos
2. Al pastor tacos
3. Carne asada torta

The things I've not liked so much are the horchata (one day really good, next time not so good) and the carnitas (can be found elsewhere much better).  In addition, it's a bit pricey for a taco truck.

Best part?  I always have an excuse to go because it's really close to Costco.
author: Amy K.

description: I love their grilled chicken tacos! I order them with guacamole and spicy sauce/toppings. I order 2 if I'm not that hungry but usually I go for 3. You can pick up your big screen tv or play the latest video game while you wait. What could be better? That's right. Nothing!
author: Sandy H.

description:
Alright  so you would think "roach coach" if you saw one of these but surprisingly enough my 1st experience was down in LA @ a King Taco Truck and was wooed.  I was reluctant to try one one of these here in the city until a friend(a frequent customer) took me there after a cruise through Best Buy.  
4 Carne Asada's please Spicy, and an orange Jarito. I'm getting hungry now just thinking about it.
author: Nerdy G.

description:
I must admit that I've only ever had tortas two separate times until the other day. Burritos and tacos every which way most of the times, but again only two tortas.  The first time was a carnitas torta at a taco stand on mission and van ness (?) a few years ago -- didn't really care for it but the place was near my office at the time.  The 2nd carnitas torta adventure was at Frontera's a little over a month ago over at Macy's Union Square's food court -- was ok, again didn't really care for it and again was near my new office. Told myself to stick with burritos.

Black Friday-ish shopping arrives and the slow torta adventure continues. I've walked, biked, and driven by the taco truck enroute to Best Buy for years -- never once giving any thought to trying the food. So, after shopping at BB, I decided to head over to the "stupidly long ignored by me" El Tonyense Taco truck.  Let me just say....The 3rd time was the charm!  

I had the most tastiest, awesome, tastiest, incredible, tastiest carnitas tortas ever!  Granted, it was only the third time for this sandwich, but man, it was outta this world. Did I mention it was the tastiest?  It beat the pants off the other two places and it really does beat the pants off of carnitas tacos or carnitas burritos. My mouth is watering as I am typing this now.

I've been reeled in as a F-A-N. Been back twice since...and will be going back right after I hit the submit button on this review! 

One last note as other reviewers have already mention... I swear it looks like it must be the cleanest "roach coach" in the city. Which is an "A" in my book!
author: Fish H.

description: Saw this first on Check Please Bay Area.  Excellent tacos as pastor and you can hit Best Buy after wards.  Parking readily available at BB.
author: John P.

description: I was rushing around all day trying to get stuff done so I forgot to eat.  I passed this taco truck on my way to one stop and I was reminded that I was hungry soI got the carnitas taco.  The meat was flavorful with some crunchy bits and the hot sauce was sufficiently spicy.   Parking in the Best Buy lot made  things particularly easy so next time I'm craving some pork, I'll know where to go.
author: Seong P.

description: Wow, who would have guessed something this good could come from a roach coach! I used to frequent the truck that is located on Spear and Folsom, but the quality of the food from this particular location is just so much better. The carne asada is to die for!
author: Sandy Y.

description: Yum. I was coming back from the Timbuk2 Warehouse sale and starving. Noticed the taco truck and just had to give it a go. It was well worth it. I got the Carne Asada Super Burrito - spicy no rice. It was good. Could have been spicy and needed salsa. I asked for it then forgot it once the burrito was in the bag. Damn - would have made it better I am sure. Still pretty good. Meat was the way to go. Nothing better than pulling up the curb, rolling up my pant legs and biting into a juicy burrito.
author: Doreen D.

description: I would go travel any distance for this taco truck, they have the most yummy authentic mex food. I highly recomend lengua, in any of their offerings!
author: David F.

description: one of my favorite taco trucks in the city.  the carne asada tacos with marinated jalapenos and carrots are off the hook with that hot sauce.  meat is tender, juicy and flavorful.
author: Wayne L.

description: The Best Taco's in SF come from a truck? You bet they do!
author: Michael R.

description:
Taco trucks are subjective.  One person's most favorite in the world can leave another person saying, "meh".  I understand that so I try not to get my panties in a twist about taco trucks anymore.  I used to. . .when I first moved to Oakland, land of the taco truck, I was like a little hummingbird flitting from one truck to the other in search of that one special something that sets one truck apart from the others. . .in Spanish when something is particularly delicious it is "muy rico". . .but that seems not to do it justice. . .what's the Spanish word for the Japanese word "umami"?    It's a flavor sense - a juxtaposition of savoriness . . .salty and smoky.  Salty and spicy.  Etc.

Voice in the back of my head is sort of yelling at me right now:

"Hey you. . Hey,  Lainie, you're freakin' talking about a taco truck . .. umami in a taco truck???  What are you, a poseur Chowhound?" 

El Tonayense is my favorite place for tacos.  It's a combination of all the perfect little flavors heaped together.  Their al pastor is amazing.  Not too greasy, not too dry. . the meat is chunkier than at other taco trucks and the spices have a little more depth.  The carnitas are tender and juicy - not too greasy.  The carne asada is chopped fine so you get a nice flavor without chewy meat.  The tortillas are tender and flavorful.  The salsa is deep and smokey.   I usually ask for mine without onions for two reasons. . one, the onions over power all the other flavors and 2) there is a phenomenon called taco truck breath. . .. . .so if you like the onions, make sure you have a powerful breath mint handy.  I love pickled jalapenos and the ones here are good and they are sliced in small slivers so you can just pile 'em on top of your taco instead of having to take a bite of a whole chile and then take a bite of your taco.   They also have a lot of the standard offal filings. . .tripitas (tripe), buche (neck meat), sesos (brains), lengua (tongue), and cabeza (cheek and head meat).   

This is a truck for tacos.  Burritos and tortas are only okay.  It's called a taco truck for a reason .  .. really good tacos. .. Mmmmmmm taco umami. .. mmmmmmmmmmmmm.
author: Lainie L.

description: This Taco Truck is right by my work across from Best Buy and Office Max. I usually just order the Carnitas street taco and a bag of chips and spicy salsa. It's so delicious! I once ordered their Super Burrito, but could only finish half of it. It's also very good.
author: Francine S.

description: Like the bacon dog cart, this is a good standby for a quick bite after a night of intoxication or when Taco Bell just won't do.  They serve up the standard tacos, burritos, quesadillas, and other Mexican treats.  Don't expect gourmet food...this is a taco truck.  It will satisfy the hunger down under.  Try the carnitas or the carne asada.  No cerveza though.  Also, if you go too late, you might not be able to sample beef tongue, stomach, or brains.  Vamanos!
author: JeFF T.

description: El Tonayense (in front of best buy) is amazing. Their meat is absolutely delicious. Everything I have tried there so far is very flavorful and fresh. The sauce they put in their burritos is perfect. I like to get both the mild and spicy sauces in my burrito, but both are great on their own. Their Pastor is one of my favorites, some of the best pastor I've ever had. It's so good it's not even worth describing. Just go there, you won't be disappointed.
author: Jack S.

description: Great Mexican food, served truck-side!  I have no idea what they put in the food (notice that I'm not going there.....) but the spice blend is wonderful and very unique.  The tacos are small, but very tasty, and the burritos are as big as your head, and also wonderful.  Plus, service is fast and friendly.  I haven't worked up the courage to try the lengua (tongue) or the cabesa (head cheese), and I frankly don't ever intend to, but be aware that those are options.
author: Ben P.

description:
this is my favorite burrito truck I've been to in SF thus far.  granted, I've only been to about two so far and I've heard some of the other El Tonayense Taco Trucks are actually better but that won't stop me from giving them a 5 star rating!

This place has a prime location right outside the Bestbuy on Division and is the reason I ate here the first time 'round.  There is something about their burritos that is just so perfect.  I mean, its not as good as say 2009's Burrito of the Year winner Papalote (according to SFGate) but for a Burrito truck, its about as good as its got to get!  The burritos were chock full of meat, beans, and some kind of delicious sauce that we probably don't want to ask too many questions about but sure do enjoy chomping down upon.  All I have to say is that whenever I drive by this place I have to fight a bit of an urge to stop by - I'll make some excuse about checking out the sales on bigscreen TVs at Best Buy but deep down I know why I'm REALLY stopping :)  I've probably just had the carne asade but I'm sure everything else is delicious as well.  Have one in the parking lot or take it to go!
author: jacob l.

description:
I swear they add lard in their boritto flour tortillas.  It has this flavor that is very familiar to other fatty foods I salivate over.  Great price, close to work, and cleans my insides out every time.  I come here when I get a craving.  That only happens every other month since the stomachaches keeps the "must have" cravings to a "might want".

Carne asada is just okay.  The beef they use seems to be a cheaper cut and over cooked.  Almost like they use chuck or something that I don't consider to be Carne asada.

5 stars for a tasty tortilla.
1 star for the cracks in my white Kholer throne.
5 stars for price.
5 stars for location.
1 star for crappy beef.
author: Christopher C.

description: Listen if your gonna do it up, do it up right. When it comes to burritos and tacos, this truck has the most bang for your buck. I have been to this location numerous amounts of time and it's always been consistent and delicious. Ive had everything from toungue to cheek in this truck and it's all good. If you want the real deal scene - Al Pastor Super Burrito........A tastebud explosion is the best way to describe it, don't ask questions just get it and we can talk about it later....
author: Scotty G.

description:
so...i work literally like 100 feet from it.

i didnt know the area very well when i started my job so having a taco truck parked outside was a godsend. it immediately became one of my staples as im a huge fan of good ol street food. its cheap...made to order...and YUMMY. 

the tacos are piled high with the meat of your choice and with a spicy sauce and lime wedges i happily gobble them down each time. 

the only bone i have to pick with them is the plates are too damn flimsy for the food. id be terribly sad if one of my beloved tacos dropped to the floor because the plate folded =(.
author: Jaime W.

description: Love the taco carnitas with EXTRA spicy salsa.  I admit the only times I'm able to hit the truck is whenever I have to swing by Best Buy to consume electronic/accessory crap.
author: Trinity M.

description: Parking one of these trucks across from Best Buy is just brilliant. I can get my gadget fix and Mexican food fix all in one stop! Burritos are excellent and quick though half the stuff on the menu just plain scares me.
author: Jan Michael K.

description: Two chicken tacos with spicy salsa verde: $3.50. Knowing you're in on one of those only-in-San Francisco super-tasty secrets: priceless.
author: Ben G.

description: If you're only going to try one thing here, go with the tortas. The bread is soft, the lettuce and tomato are fresh, the salsa is just the right spiciness, and the meat is really good (I like the carne asada and al pastor the best). The tacos are also highly recommended, but their burritos are just so-so. Also get a horchata or mexican coke to wash it all down and you'll be a happy person afterwards.  This is a fun place to go when you want a cheap, quick meal by yourself or with friends.
author: Kevin M.

description: Mmmm... taco truck goodness.   Cheap, amazingly good burritos.... so good... so very very good.  I had mine spicy, and the level of spice was good... my mouth had a lingering burn for a couple of minutes after getting done.   Tons of choices, which bodes well for future visits.  Also, and as other reviewers have noted, the truck seems to be kept cleaner than many resteraunts I have been to.   Perhaps the best thing the Best Buy has going for it.
author: Alured P.

description: A pretty spectacular carnitas taco disappeared in four bites. For $1.75, it's a bit toward the luxury end of the scale. I overheard a guy grumbling, en español, that equivalent tacos are only $0.50 in Los Angeles. Welcome to SF, baby!
author: Maximillian M.

description: Writing yelp reviews has made me realize that I'll give a 4-5 rating if a place just does one thing exceptionally well. The taco truck is a perfect example. I've never tried anything but the tacos and I'm not sure I ever need to. I think they're the best authentic tacos in the city. The corn tortillas are great but it's the meat that makes them. I've tried every kind of chicken, pork, and beef variety they have...all are exceptional. And next time, I'm planning to adventure with the cabeza (brain), lengua (tongue), and tripitas (tripe). Wish me luck.
author: Bill R.

description: As far as taco trucks go, this one is fine. Delicious, even. The output is hugely variable, so I can't really attest to any particular experience there. Typically, though, the al pastor is lovely, and there are handsome people biking by. If a girl comes out of the design shop across the street she will smile at you, and you will have meat all over your face. Face it, pig, you belong inside Best Buy with the rest of the fatties.
author: Tim S.

description: I was hungry and after parking at Best Buy, the taco truck caught my eye. Not having eating off a taco truck in over 5 years, I was a bit hesitant, but reassured that it was a-ok and their reputation was stellar.  I ordered a veggie taco and a grilled chicken taco. Each $1.50 and both delicious. They made it real quick and it satisfied my hunger pains. The green salsa was also very delicious and no spicy. I'm a fan!
author: Natalie S.

description: Dammit I think I went to the wrong one since the one on 22nd seems to be rated higher.  But I was in the neighborhood when I spotted the truck, so I had to stop and try the taco al pastor.  The pork pieces could have been more tender but the flavoring was pretty close.  It almost came together spice wise, but Taqueria San Jose is still my favorite in SF.  I guess I can still try the other Tonayense truck...
author: Derrick V.

description: Got an al pastor and carne asada taco here.  Found out that it was the same people of the taco truck closer to my work place on harrison st and 22nd.  Same prices, same menu, same taste, but further away.  I'll give it 4 stars for easy parking at the best buy parking lot.
author: Danny P.

description: Yo quiero Tonayense tacos.  Me gusta.  Their soft tacos are delicious, even better than at some of the Mission dist places on Valencia.  Their grilled chicken (pollo asada) is crispy and well-seasoned.  The lengue (tongue) is tender. Didn't like the carnitas (pork) as much.  Their burritos are the same price as Gordo's and for $5.50 you get a burrito full of meat, a lot of meat, beans, not so much rice compared to Gordo's.  They are generous with the meat.  You can have mild or hot sauce.  The tacos are place on a paper plate and covered with foil of you're taking it "to go". They serve horchata and bottled sangria too. Great place to catch a bite, take it home, stand there to enjoy or eat in your car.
author: Ry T.

description: I haven't come here in a while because the aforementioned coworker left, but I still think about taking the trip by myself. I've started liking burritos in general and have been going elsewhere, but I remember the subtle chipotle flavor of El Tonayense's burrito and look forward to coming back.
author: Amy Z.

description: I guess by giving it 4 stars I'm considered a fan.  Honestly, I'm I have mix feelings about the taco truck. It is a TACO TRUCK and for crying out loud 6 freaking bucks for a burrito from a truck- are you kidding me??
